name: Carly Cushnie
title: Fashion designer
fraud: Lawsuit: Co-founder Michelle Ochs sued Cushnie brand (Jun 2020) for $360K+ in unpaid settlement payments after business split.

name: Sophia Amoruso
title: Fashion Retailer
fraud: Bankruptcy: Nasty Gal filed Chapter 11 (Nov 2016). Multiple lawsuits for wrongful termination/pregnancy discrimination (2015+).

name: Michael Avedon
title: Photographer
company: The grandson of master photographer Richard Avedon, he is currently a student at the International Center of Photography in New York City. He works primarily with black & white 35mm and medium format film.

name: Sam Falls
title: Artist
company: Falls uses photography, Photoshop, drawing, painting and sculpture to make artworks that combine abstract and figurative images. He has had solo shows in New York, Miami, Stockholm and Madrid and group exhibitions in more than a dozen cities including Brussels, London, Amsterdam and Philadelphia.

name: JR
title: Artist
company: A French conceptual artist who chooses to remain anonymous, JR hangs massive photos in public spaces, including giant pictures of eyes staring down from a Rio de Janeiro slum and portraits of Arabs and Jews hung all over Israel and the West Bank. He has shown at theTate Modern and the Centre Pompidou, and won a TED prize in 2011.
fraud: Began as a graffiti artist and moved in the direction of popularly accepted murals

name: Jacob Kassay
title: Artist
company: Kassay's minimalist, mirror-like silver canvases have fetched as much as $290,500 at auction. He has had solo shows in Los Angeles, New York, Brussels and Paris, and his work is in museum collections including the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston and the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago.

name: Max Levai
title: Gallery Owner
fraud: Was convicted for defrauding Mark Rothko and his estate

name: Pedro Lourenço
title: Fashion Designer
company: A much buzzed-about name among fashion insiders, Brazilian Lourenço showed his first ready-to-wear collection in Paris to critical acclaim when he was just 19. Born into a fashion family, both his mother and father are established designers in Sao Paulo--Lourenço is more than familiar with the inner workings of the rag trade. Recent collections have included aviator-inspired shirts, cropped pants and psychedelic print bomber jackets.

name: Leandra Medine
title: Fashion Blogger
fraud: Controversy: Stepped down from Man Repeller (Jun 2020) after accusations of racism and lack of diversity in content/employees.

name: Toyin Odutola
title: Artist
company: Using ballpoint pens and other drawing utensils, Nigerian-born Odutola makes intricate portraits from photographs. She has had a one-woman show at the Jack Shainman gallery in New York City, and exhibited in group shows at the Menil Collection in Houston and at the Studio Museum in Harlem.

name: Ashley & Mary Kate Olsen
title: Fashion Designers
company: The Row, Elizabeth and James, Olsenboye, StyleMint
fraud: Lawsuit: Settled unpaid intern class action (2015-2017) for $140K. Sued by former exec (2020) for wrongful termination.

name: Adam Pendleton
title: Artist
company: Moving between painting, photography, and performance to create works that deal with race and language, Pendleton pairs seemingly unrelated concepts to force viewers to rethink the meaning of each. He has shown at the Museum of Modern Art, the Whitney, the New Museum in New York City, and internationally, including at the once-every-three-year exhibition at the Palais de Tokyo in Paris.

name: Vladimir Roitfeld
title: Art Dealer
company: Raised in Paris, Roitfeld moved to L.A. at age 18 to study film at the University of Southern California. Disillusioned with Hollywood months after landing a job at Paramount, he hit Manhattan in early 2008 and teamed up with Australian heir Andy Valmorbida to stage exhibits in large venues off the beaten path, where the crowds and loud music wouldn't afflict the neighborhood. They split in 2011, though each continues to show. Roitfeld held a large sale at Sotheby's this fall.

name: Vito Schnabel
title: Art Dealer
company: Son of artist Julian Schnabel, he staged his first temporary art exhibition at age 16. He curates shows in various venues around the world and is known for matching artworks to a show's setting, using such varied locations as a cornfield in Long Island and a cloistered garden in Venice. Schnabel works with both established and emerging artists, including a show of performance artist Laurie Anderson's paintings.

name: Lucien Smith
title: Artist
company: Smith is a New York painter and sculptor who has shown at prestigious shows in New York, LA, Miami Basel, and London. He received a BFA in painting from the Cooper Union School of Art and frequently incorporates layered oil on canvas with bits of molding paste and detritus mixed in. Noted gallerist David Zwirner has named him as an artist to watch.

name: Artie Vierkant
title: Digital artist
company: Trained in photography, Vierkant makes one-of-a-kind abstract pieces suffused with light and bright colors, using Photoshop, a large-scale printer and pieces of layered plastic. He also works in video. He has had one-man shows in L.A., New York and Richmond, Va., and has participated in some 20 group shows, including in London, Berlin, Amsterdam and Glasgow.

name: Alexander Wang
title: Fashion Designer
fraud: Sexual misconduct: Multiple allegations of sexual assault (2020-2021) from models/trans women. Lawsuit filed and settled. Issued public apology.

name: B.O.B.
title: Ambassador
fraud: In late 2025, was sued by a woman alledging he held her hostage and S.A.'ed her in a San Diego hotel room

name: Jon Cetel
title: Founding Executive Director
fraud: PennCAN was caught secretly advising Pennsylvania Gov. Tom Corbett that forcing major contract concessions from Philadelphia teachers could help his bid for re-election

name: Marisa Urrutia Gedney
title: Director of Operations and Programming, Echo Park

name: Nikhil Goyal
title: Author
company: Graduating high school in January, Goyal is the author of "One Size Does Not fit All: A Student's Assessment of School." His premise? That the U.S. education system does not serve every student--and that perhaps the "school of life" is the better place to learn.

name: Andrew Grauer
title: Cofounder
fraud: Course Hero has taken public works and paywalled them without permission (e.g. Mirrlees)

name: Jeremiah Kittredge
title: Executive Director
fraud: Got ousted for alleged misconduct and settled a large campaign-finance violation penalty

name: Leslie Dewan
title: Chief Science Officer
fraud: Certain claims helped it raise millions in venture capital, secure a series of glowing media profiles, and draw a rock-star lineup of technical advisors. In a paper on its site dated November 2016, the company downgraded “75 times” to “more than twice.” In addition, it now specifies that the design “does not reduce existing stockpiles of spent nuclear fuel” or use them as its fuel source. The promise of recycling nuclear waste, which poses tricky storage and proliferation challenges, was a key initial attraction of the company and captured considerable attention.

name: Trisha Andrew
title: Organic Chemist
company: 2011 L'Oreal USA For Women in Science Fellow

name: Danielle Fong
title: Chief Science Officer
fraud: Quoted to have been profitably selling energy tanks in 2014/2015 but also having reported shipping their first product in a tweet in March 2016

name: Alexander Miller
title: Assistant Professor
company: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

name: Meredith Perry
title: Founder
fraud: Sued and sued by her co-founder (uBeam)

name: Joshua Kushner
title: Founder
fraud: Owns half of JK2 (also known as Westminster Management) with his brother

name: Martin Shkreli
title: Founder
fraud: Convicted securities fraud/conspiracy. Sentenced 7 years prison (Mar 2018). Released May 2022.

name: Natasha Case
title: Cofounder
fraud: Dairy-Free Horchata Frozen Dessert Sandwich contained undeclared milk

name: Grant Gordon
title: Executive Chef
company: Montrose Restaurant Associates; Gateway Restaurant Associates

name: Adam Leonti
title: Chef de Cuisine
fraud: Lawsuit with Williamsburg Hotel and accused of stealing secrets

name: Jeff Mahin
title: Chef
company: Stella Rossa Pizza Bar, Do-Rite Donuts

name: Anthony Burch
title: Lead Writer
fraud: Allegedly used his position to offer people a job at Gearbox and subsequently dump them after a period of dating

name: Zain Jaffer
title: CEO
fraud: Charges were dropped following conclusion of a psychotic episode triggered by a cocktail of prescription drugs prescribed to him by doctors. Got fired after being arrested and charged with performing a lewd act on one of his children, as well as child abuse and battery.

name: Palmer Luckey
title: CEO
fraud: Lawsuit: ZeniMax v. Oculus - $500M jury verdict (2017) for NDA violation and trade secret misappropriation. Later cleared of IP theft on appeal (2021).

name: Apoorva Mehta
title: Founder
fraud: Apoorva Mehta, co-founder of Instacart, has faced significant legal scrutiny, including a 2022 lawsuit alleging he used stolen trade secrets to create a "copycat" company (Cloud Health Systems). Instacart under his leadership faced lawsuits over misclassified workers, and post-IPO, faced investor suits regarding misleading disclosures.

name: Matt Nava
title: Concept Artist
company: Otis College of Art and Design

name: Emmett Shear
title: CEO
fraud: He faced criticism for his handling of sexual abuse claims made against some streamers, and in 2020 apologised to those who felt his response had been "dismissive".

name: Kevin Systrom
title: CEO
fraud: Emails surfaced showing Systrom was included in discussions about cutting off competitors' access to API data, such as with Twitter's Vine app.

name: Aziz Ansari
title: Actor, Writer
company: Best known for his work on the NBC show "Parks and Recreation," Ansari also has a thriving movie career and a busy standup schedule. He recently took a page from the book of Louis C.K.by selling digital copies of his standup special "Dangerously Delicious" direct to fans for $5.

name: Maude Apatow
title: Actor, Writer
company: Judd Apatow's daughter made her film debut in dad's 2007 "Knocked Up" as the daughter of a character played by her real-life mother, Leslie Mann. This year she revisted that role in the sort-of sequel, "This Is 40." Apatow has also become a well-followed tweeter and writer, contributing to Zooey Deschanel's website HelloGiggles.

name: Jencarlos Canela
title: Actor, Singer
company: Canela is well-known on Spanish-language network Telemundo, where he's starred in four telenovelas including "Mas Sabe el Diablo" (“The Devil Knows Best”). But he's also a budding pop star. Canela sang the theme song for three of his TV shows. Telemundo featured his song "Suena" during its Olympic coverage. At least one of our judges believes Canela has a good chance to cross over.

name: Sam Claflin
title: Actor
company: Claflin has had small roles in movies like "Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides" and "Snow White and the Huntsman." But Hollywood is expecting him to really breakout in next year's "Catching Fire," the second in "The Hunger Games" series. Claflin will play fan favorite Finnick Odair.

name: Chris Colfer
title: Actor, Writer
company: Colfer is best known for playing Kurt Hummel on "Glee," but the young actor is quietly moving beyond TV. He wrote a best-selling children's book, "The Land of Stories,” and recently produced an independent movie,"Struck By Lightning." Colfer also wrote and stars in the film which will hit theaters in January.

name: Lena Dunham
title: Writer, Director, Actor
company: Dunham's HBO show is a bona fide hit and whether she wants to be or not, she is now the voice of her generation. The writer/director/actress recently scored a $3.5 million advance for a book of essays. Season 2 of "Girls" starts in January.
fraud: Performed lewd acts on her sister when young

name: Greta Gerwig
title: Actor, Writer
company: Gerwig charmed Hollywood with her turn as Ben Stiller's love interest in the little-seen "Greenberg." Now she's writing her own material. Her latest, "Frances Ha," directed by boyfriend Noah Baumbach, was a huge hit at the recent New York Film Festival.

name: Ariana Grande
title: Actor
company: For the past two and a half years, Grande has played second-fiddle to Victoria Justice on the Nickolodeon show "Victorious." Now she's getting her own spin-off show. Her character, Cat Valentine, is moving in with Sam Puckett from "iCarly" on the new show "Sam and Cat."
fraud: Lawsuits: Sued Forever 21 for $10M (2019) - unauthorized likeness. Sued for '7 Rings' copyright (2020). 'One Last Time' plagiarism suit (2016). Cultural appropriation/blackfishing controversy. Filing DMCA notices against critics.

name: Nicholas Hoult
title: Actor
company: Hoult made his acting debut in the 2001 movie "About A Boy" with Hugh Grant, but 2013 is looking like it will be Hoult's true breakout year. In February he'll star as a zombie in love (you read that right) in "Warm Bodies." Then in March he headlines Warner Bros.' take on the classic fairy tale "Jack the Giant Slayer."

name: Max Landis
title: Writer, Director
company: Landis' debut film was last year's "Chronicle," a sort of found-footage movie about a group of Seattle teens who end up with superpowers. The dark film was a hit earning $127 million on a budget of $12 million. Now Landis has a chance to direct. "Me Him Her," which Landis also wrote, has been describe as "Reality Bites" on acid.

name: Logan Lerman
title: Actor
company: Lerman was in line to be the next Daniel Radcliffe with "Percy Jackson." But the first film in the franchise didn't do quite as well as expected. Instead, Lerman is making his mark in smaller films like "The Perks of Being a Wallflower." He'll return to Percy Jackson next year in "Sea of Monsters."

name: Chloe Moretz
title: Actor
company: Moretz is well on her way to becoming one of Hollywood's biggest stars. Only 15, she's shown she can hold her own in violent pictures like "Kick-Ass" and "Let Me In." Now she's taking on the iconic role of Carrie White in an update of the Stephen King horror classic. Expect to see Moretz on our Celebrity 100 in the next decade.

name: Issa Rae
title: Web Star
fraud: On July 30, 2025, three Los Angeles-based screenwriters—Tyrone Perry, Shon Oku, and Joshua Isaacson—filed a lawsuit against Issa Rae's company, Hoorae, and other producers.

name: Nev Schulman
title: Filmmaker
fraud: Expelled from university for punching a woman, claimed to have been done in self defense

name: Analeigh Tipton
title: Actor
company: Tipton has gone from coming in third on "America's Next Top Model" to one of Hollywood's hottest up and coming actresses in just four years. She stood out in last year's "Crazy, Stupid Love" as a babysitter with a crush on Steve Carrell. She'll next appear in "Warm Bodies," a zombie love story.

name: Rebel Wilson
title: Actress/Writer
company: Ask anyone in Hollywood who the most promising young comedian is today and they'll tell you Rebel Wilson. The Australian actress stood out in a small role as Kristen Wiig's roommate in "Bridesmaids". Then she helped make the tiny "Pitch Perfect" a hit. Now she's hard at work on her first American sitcom, "Super Fun Night" which she wrote, produces and is starring in.

name: Martha Bloem
title: Senior Program Officer
company: Scholar Rescue Fund, Institute of International Education

name: Max Bruner
title: Truman Scholar
company: Center for Strategic and International Studies

name: Ronan Farrow
title: Rhodes Scholar
company: Mia Farrow and Woody Allen's son was accepted to Yale Law at 16, advised State Department on youth affairs and is now a Rhodes Scholar.

name: Andrew Kloster
title: Fellow
company: Foundation for Individual Rights in Education

name: Nate Loewentheil
title: Writer
company: Founded the Roosevelt Campus Network while an undergraduate at Yale University. Now in his third year at Yale Law School, writes frequently for The New York Times and Politico, among others, and co-authored "Prosperity Economics: Building an Economy For All.”

name: Anthony Giordano
title: Director of Marketing and Business Development, North America

name: Maarten Peschier
title: Senior Technology Scientist, Emerging Media Lab

name: Matt Mullenweg
title: Founder
fraud: WP Engine sued Automattic and Mullenweg for abuse of power, attempted extortion, and libel. Mullenweg took, then retracted, hostile actions against WP Engine.

name: Jimmy Soni
title: Managing Editor
fraud: Left HuffPo following rumors of an investigation related to sexual harassment in the workplace

name: Wiz Khalifa
title: Musician
fraud: Received various drug and money related lawsuits both locally and abroad

name: Adele
title: Musician
company: If the recorded music industry is dying, the big-voiced Brit didn't get the memo: her album 21 has sold over 23 million copies worldwide.
fraud: Ordered by Brazilian judge to remove a song from streaming platforms due to alleged copying of a 1995 samba track

name: Avicii
title: Musician
company: The young Swede picked up a Grammy nomination -- and, thanks to six-figure fees for live shows, a spot on FORBES' inaugural top-earning DJs list.
fraud: His estate is currently being sued by Avicii's former manager under the accusation of slander

name: Justin Bieber
title: Musician
company: The Canadian crooner released his third album, launched a new world tour and continued investing in startups on his way to a $55 million payday this year, earning him a spot on the cover of FORBES in June.
fraud: Multiple lawsuits: Settled assault lawsuits with bodyguard (2014) and photographers (2016). Toronto assault charge. Drag race settlement ($50K). Filed $20M defamation suit (2020).

name: Benny Blanco
title: Producer
company: With production and songwriting credits on smash singles like Maroon 5's "Payphone" and Rihanna's "Diamonds," Blanco is quickly becoming an industry powerhouse.

name: Drake
title: Musician
company: The former Degrassi star earned $20 million last year, buoyed by live shows, a new album and endorsements with the likes of Sprite and Kodak.
fraud: Lawsuits: RICO class action (Jan 2026) alleging use of illegal online casino Stake funds ($100M/year) to inflate streams with bots. Defamation suit against UMG over Kendrick Lamar's 'Not Like Us' - dismissed (Oct 2025). Major feud with Kendrick Lamar including pedophilia accusations.

name: Daniel Ek
title: Cofounder
fraud: A class-action lawsuit filed in Nov. 2025 alleges that Spotify’s "Discovery Mode" operates like illegal payola, allowing major labels to pay for better promotion, violating the platform's promise of tailored recommendations.

name: Lady Gaga
title: Musician
company: Though she's been making fewer headlines of late, Gaga continues to rake in cash from music sales, touring and new fragrance Fame.
fraud: California surf brand Lost International filed a $100 million lawsuit alleging trademark infringement, claiming Lady Gaga's "Mayhem" merchandise logo (for her album/tour) was "substantially similar" to their own, which they have used since 2015. In December 2025, a federal judge ruled in favor of Lady Gaga, determining that her use of the word "Mayhem" did not infringe on the surf brand's trademark.

name: Skylar Grey
title: Musician
company: The singer-songwriter wrote the hook to Eminem and Rihanna's "Love The Way You Lie," which earned five Grammy nominations; she's set for her major label solo debut in 2013.

name: Calvin Harris
title: Musician
company: The Scottish DJ has successfully crossed over into the pop world with hits like his Rihanna collaboration "We Found Love," adding to his coffers with healthy profits on the road.
fraud: In May 2025, British producer Chicane accused Calvin Harris of sampling his 90s trance hit "Offshore" without permission in the track "Blessings." Harris engaged in a public social media war of words, dismissing the claims and labeling Chicane's actions as a "fierce plagiarism" accusation.

name: Ke$ha
title: Musician
company: Take some glitter, a bit of dirt, mix in some catchy pop hooks and you get Ke$ha, the hard-partying embodiment of a generation. Smash single "Die Young" should keep her star rising.
fraud: In 2016, a judge denied Kesha an injunction to record outside of Dr. Luke's label. Subsequent rulings found Kesha defamed Dr. Luke, including false claims that he assaulted Katy Perry.

name: Kendrick Lamar
title: Musician
company: Dr. Dre's newest protege appears set for stardom with the launch of album Good Kid, M.A.A.D City, which debuted with sales of 242,000 its opening week.
fraud: Tryna strike a chord and it's probably A minorrrrrr

name: Bruno Mars
title: Musician
company: He may not be a billionaire, but the pop singer-songwriter now grosses a quarter of a million dollars a night on the road -- and he did get his picture in FORBES.
fraud: Rumors from March 2024 claimed Bruno Mars owed over $50 million in gambling debt to MGM Resorts, alleging they "owned" him due to his Las Vegas residency.

name: Mac Miller
title: Musician
company: The Pittsburgh native followed local pal Wiz Khalifa to hip-hop stardom, earning a spot as the featured artist on last year's 30 Under 30 -- and $6.5 million.
fraud: Mac Miller faced a significant $10 million sampling lawsuit from rapper Lord Finesse over the unauthorized use of an instrumental on the K.I.D.S. mixtape, which was settled. Other notable controversies included a 2013 lawsuit threat from Donald Trump regarding his song "Donald Trump" and online backlash targeting Ariana Grande following his 2018 death.

name: Marcus Mumford
title: Musician
company: Folksy frontman and his indie rock act Mumford & Sons shocked the world by selling over 600,000 copies of their new album, Babel, in its opening week -- the second-best debut of the year.

name: Frank Ocean
title: Musician
company: Buoyed by the success of hip-hop collective Odd Future, Ocean has established himself as a solo act, earning six Grammy nominations this year, tied for the most of any artist.

name: Katy Perry
title: Musician
company: This "California Gurl" joined Michael Jackson as the only artist to have five No. 1 singles from the same album; she continues to pad her coffers with touring, endorsements and a biopic.
fraud: Katy Perry has been involved in a contentious, years-long lawsuit against 85-year-old disabled veteran Carl Westcott over a $15 million Montecito, California home she purchased in 2020. Despite Westcott’s claim that he was incapacitated by pain medication during the sale, a judge ruled in Perry's favor, and in late 2025, she was awarded $1.8 million in damages for lost rental income.

name: Rihanna
title: Musician
company: The Barbados-born diva has parlayed pop hits into endorsements with Vita Coco and Nivea, fragrance Reb'l Fleur and sold-out shows around the world.
fraud: Her lingerie company, Savage X Fenty, paid $1.2 million to settle a lawsuit from California local governments alleging deceptive marketing and hidden subscription fees.

name: Skrillex
title: Musician
company: The side-mulletted DJ brought dubstep music to the mainstream. Now he earns six figures for live performances and makes music for movies like Wreck-It Ralph.

name: Taylor Swift
title: Musician
company: New album Red moved 1.2 million units its opening week, the best debut since 2002. Swift also earns big from endorsements with the likes of CoverGirl and grosses over $1 million for live shows.

name: Cindy Chang
title: Medical Student
company: Cleveland Clinic Lerner College of Medicine

name: Pierce Graham-Jones
title: West Health Innovator-in-Residence
company: Department of Health and Human Services

name: Jillian Shapiro
title: Graduate Student
company: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

name: Lily Liu
title: Cofounder
fraud: Solana Foundation President Lily Liu was named as a defendant in a July 2025 amended complaint regarding a $5.5B RICO class-action lawsuit against Pump.fun and Solana. The lawsuit alleges she and other senior leadership were involved in unlawful activities related to the memecoin platform.

name: Deron Williams
title: Point Guard
fraud: During the 2011 lockout, Williams was involved in the antitrust lawsuits filed by NBA players against the league, according to MLive and Bleacher Report.

name: Usain Bolt
title: Sprinter
company: The six-time Olympic gold medalist has been dubbed the "World's Most Marketable Athlete" by the website SportsPromedia.com, which notes that he "brings the promise of something historic with every appearance." Bolt's $9 million a year deal with Puma is the biggest ever for a track & field athlete.
fraud: 2017 Doping Scandal: Bolt lost his 2008 4x100m relay gold medal after teammate Nesta Carter failed a re-tested sample for a prohibited stimulant.

name: Anthony Davis
title: Forward
fraud: The NBA fined Anthony Davis $50,000—the maximum amount permitted without filing a grievance—for violating a collective bargaining rule prohibiting players or agents from making public trade demands.

name: Bryce Harper
title: Outfielder
fraud: During a scheduled visit, Harper reportedly told Commissioner Manfred to "get the f--- out of our clubhouse" after the discussion turned to the potential implementation of a salary cap.

name: Dwight Howard
title: Center
fraud: Lawsuit: Sexual assault lawsuit filed (2023), dismissed Aug 2024 after plaintiff dropped case. Also child abuse allegations and harassment claims.

name: LeBron James
title: Forward
fraud: In October 2025, LeBron James was sued in small claims court by a fan alleging "fraud" and "deception" over a hyped "Second Decision" social media post that turned out to be a Hennessy advertisement rather than a retirement announcement. The suit was dismissed after the fan was compensated.

name: Derrick Rose
title: Point Guard
fraud: In 2015 and 2016, former Chicago Bulls star Derrick Rose was involved in a high-profile civil lawsuit concerning allegations of sexual assault, a controversy that significantly impacted his reputation during his final season with the Bulls and subsequent move to the New York Knicks.

name: Ronda Rousey
title: MMA Fighter
fraud: Ronda Rousey, a former Strikeforce and UFC champion, has navigated several controversies, including a 2016 settled lawsuit with her ex-manager, criticism of WWE's culture, and a 2024 apology for past Sandy Hook conspiracy theories.

name: Nate Blecharczyk
title: CTO
fraud: Nate Blecharczyk was involved in managing the company's legal battles regarding data sharing with cities like New York, aiming to prove regulations could work without total bans Airbnb dismisses data-sharing lawsuit against New York City.

name: Alexis Ohanian
title: Cofounder
fraud: Does not mention Aaron Swartz as cofounder officially

name: Parisa Tabriz
title: Security Princess
fraud: Google's Chrome general manager, Parisa Tabriz, testified that it would be difficult to recreate Chrome's features and functionality without its interdependencies on other parts of Google.

name: Lucas Duplan
description: Founder, Clinkle. Just over a year after receiving his undergrad computer science degree from Stanford, Duplan is running one of the most hyped and controversial startups in the nation, Clinkle, which seeks to disrupt the way financial transactions are done—with a digital wallet used on mobile phones. He has shocked Silicon Valley with his ability to raise $30 million from the likes of Richard Branson, Peter Thiel and Andreessen Horowitz for an unreleased secret product and attract talent like former Netflix CFO

name: Luis Alvarado
description: Investment research analyst, Wells Fargo Private Bank. Youngest member of Wells Fargo Private Bank investment team, which decides the allocation for $170 billion in managed assets. Solely responsible for building capital market assumptions, forming the foundation of recommendations for virtually every client account.

name: George Bachiashvili
description: Founder, Georgian Co-Investment Fund. Runs a $6 billion private equity fund in Georgia that amounts to about 40% of the country's GDP. Backed by Georgia's own billionaire prime minister, who invested the initial $1 billion, creating some controversy around its investments in the Georgian economy. UAE's Abu Dhabi Group and China's Milestone International are among other big investors.
fraud: He faces charges of embezzling Ivanishvili's 8,253.13 Bitcoins (valued over $39 million in 2017) and legalizing illegal income, which he denies as political persecution. Sentenced in absentia to 11 years after fleeing Georgia, he claims abduction. His parents also face related money laundering charges.

name: Lucy Baldwin
description: Managing director, Goldman Sachs. Director of Goldman's European research management team and serving on the investment review committee. Previously headed Goldman's European retail and consumer equity research.

name: Sam Barnett
description: Founder, SBB Research Group. Part scientist, part mathematician, Barnett started his quant hedge fund while still a CalTech undergrad and has since grown it into a $115 million firm with 15 employees. Returns have been solid.

name: Ganesh Betanabhatla
description: Managing director, Talara Capital. Former JPMorgan oil & gas investment banker and vice president at Pine Brook Partners, now backed with up to $500 million heading Talara's private equity efforts in the energy sector.
fraud: Disappeared following a promise to invest $200M into The Metals Company

name: Tracy Britt Cool
description: Financial assistant to the chairman, Berkshire Hathaway. Emerging as an influential figure in Warren Buffett's organization. Chairman at Benjamin Moore, Johns Manville, Larson-Juhl and Oriental Trading. Also on the board of H.J. Heinz.
fraud: Complaints focused on allegations that Berkshire Hathaway and 3G Capital insiders, including Britt Cool, sold stock while in possession of negative information.

name: Rushabh Doshi
description: Trader, DW Investment Management. Former Morgan Stanley and Brevan Howard trader, specializing in high-yield and distressed debt at Brevan's external credit asset manager. Born in Mumbai; spent his teens in Topeka, KS.

name: Leigh Drogen
description: Founder, Estimize. Founded company becoming popular on Wall Street by essentially crowdsourcing estimates for key data points on financial earnings releases. In an attempt to achieve greater precision, Estimize gathers information from independent, buy-side and sell-side analysts, together with those of private investors.

name: Fred Ehrsam
description: Cofounder, Coinbase. As Bitcoin gradually becomes a mainstream phenomenon, Coinbase is trying to make it easy to use. The former Goldman Sachs currency trader is attempting to build "the PayPal for Bitcoin"; Coinbase is trying to make cryptocurrency accessible to the everyday consumer and merchant. Has raised $30 million from high profile VCs like Andreessen Horowitz, making it the top-funded Bitcoin start-up.

name: Eric Eisner
description: VP, Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Banking and Markets. Manages all Latin America low-beta sovereign debt trading for BofA Merrill. Low-beta trading was viewed as unprofitable and boring before he took over. He’s since turned it into a revenue generator for BofA trading over $30 billion in bonds and transforming the unit into a top-three top-franchise among big bank competitors.

name: Stephen Ensley
description: Principal, Hellman & Friedman. Former JPMorgan mergers & acquisitions investment banker, now a principal for one of the most well-respected private equity firms. Has helped lead portfolio investments in companies like Pharmaceutical Product Development. Sits on the board of CarProof, a Canadian vehicle history report provider.

name: Brian Feinstein
description: Partner, Bessemer Venture Partners. Started as an analyst and moved up to become the youngest partner in BVP’s 100+ year history. Now runs its Brazil and Russia investment team while also focusing on Internet and software opportunities in U.S. and Europe. Led a $10 million investment in a Brazilian mobile gaming company that’s since doubled its revenue.

name: Eugene Gokhvat
description: Portfolio manager, BlueCrest Capital Management. Worked for Boaz Weinstein on Deutsche Bank's prop desk. Now, manages his own large corporate bond portfolio at the U.S. outpost of a $35 billion European hedge fund.

name: Cameron Horwitz
description: Research director, U.S. Capital Advisors. Heads oil & gas exploration and development research at boutique Texas financial firm. Big calls on companies like Pioneer Natural Resources helped get him singled out as a"rising star" on Institutional Investor's influential research rankings.

name: Kevin Kaiser
description: Managing director, Hedgeye Risk Management. Has recently managed to spark the ire of two billionaires with high-profile, negative calls on two major stocks. Following his recomendation to short Kinder Morgan, CEO Richard Kinder held a conference call to dispute his allegations. His comments on Linn Energy helped provoke hedge fund manager Leon Cooperman, a major shareholder of the MLP.

name: Katie Keenan
description: Principal, Blackstone Group. A rising star in the world's largest real estate investment management business. Helped launch Blackstone's first mortgage lending program, which has closed $2 billion of originations in five months. Led underwriting of $1.2 billion of real estate debt investments for various Blackstone vehicles.

name: Eric Khrom
description: Founder, Khrom Capital Management. Value investor backed by a major universtiy endowment. College dropout has posted some good returns while keeping a big chunk of his portfolio in cash. He manages some $40 million at the hedge fund he founded in 2008.

name: Maximilian Kuss
description: Founder, European Media Holding AG. Used the proceeds of a gaming company and software publisher he helped found to start European Media Holding, an investing vehicle that now manages 250 million euros and looks to merge digital technologies with "old economy" companies. In September, online tire retailer Tirendo, in which EMH was a founding shareholder, sold for 50 million euros to publicly traded Delticom, in which EMH later took a substantial equity stake.

name: John Locke
description: Principal, Accel Partners. Venture capital investor focusing recently on growth-stage investments in areas like cyber security. Previously led investments in payment companies like Braintree, which is being purchased by eBay for $800 million. Played golf at Princeton.

name: Carryn McLaughlin
description: Vice president, JPMorgan Chase. Earned CFP at 23 before moving to JPM Private Bank to manage a $2.7 billion book of biz as wealth manager for real estate moguls and their families.

name: Chaitanya Mehra
description: Portfolio manager, Och-Ziff Capital Management. Former Goldman Sachs trader, now a portfolio manager focusing on energy at Dan Och's $39 billion firm, one of the largest hedge funds in the world.

name: Neil Mehta
description: Founder, Greenoaks Capital. Founded Greenoaks and now manages some $600 million, investing in industries ranging from ecommerce to insurance. Hit home runs with early investments in Palantir and Coupang.

name: Vivek Ramaswamy
description: Investment analyst, QVT Financial. Co-managing one of the hedge fund industry's largest biotech-focused portfolios for Daniel Gold's hedge fund. Well known for successful investments in companies developing antiviral drugs, including for the treatment of hepatitis C. Got a Yale law degree while working at the hedge fund.
fraud: Vivek Ramaswamy Sued By Former Employees Claiming His Company Pressured Them Into Violating Securities Laws

name: Adam Rodman
description: Founder, Segra Capital Management. Former portfolio manager at Mark Hart's Corriente Advisors, now backed by his old boss and other Texas money men like Harlan Korenvaes in new macro hedge fund.

name: Matthew Schoenfeld
description: Associate, Morgan Stanley. Specialist in Morgan Stanley's risk arbitrage group. Working for years with Lawrence Summers; the duo are currently co-writing their second paper together. Has interviewed people like Dan Loeb, Robert Rubin and David Rubenstein through a Harvard Law School speaking series he founded.

name: Sam Shikiar
description: Vice president, Goldman Sachs. Heads U.S. electronic commodities trading team that focuses on metals and energy options. Previously worked in the asset management division for a quant hedge fund team on the Global Alpha and Equity Opportunities Funds.

name: Andrew Silverman
description: Vice president, Goldman Sachs. Star credit derivatives and bond trader has become one of the top distressed debt market makers in the world. Recent promotion to managing director goes into effect in 2014.

name: Jeffrey Sun
description: Executive director, Morgan Stanley. Primary trader at Morgan Stanley in oil products options, managing the investment bank's exposure to things like jet fuel and diesel. Also trades crude oil options.

name: Chris Yetter
description: Head of Latin American Investments, Falcon Edge Capital. Spearheading some very profitable investments in Latin America for $2 billion hedge fund. Former trader at QVT. Taught in Spain.

name: Olivia Wilde
description: Fundraising is the bane of every philanthropy's existence. Do-gooders go back to the same rich donors over and over trying to convince them to keep giving. Actress Olivia Wilde thinks there's a better way. That's why she's co-founded Conscious Commerce. The company pairs brands with causes to help corporations become better global citizens. So profits from a best-selling dress at Anthropolgie go to a girls' school in India. A limited edition bag at Alternative Apparel helps fund a school in Hait
fraud: Former live-in nanny Ericka Genaro sued Wilde and Sudeikis for wrongful termination, alleging she was fired for needing time off for stress related to their breakup. The suit claimed an "exponential" increase in workload after Wilde left the home. Was handed papers at Comic Con

name: Megan Amram
description: Writer-comedian. The comedian shares her blend of silly, surreal and sometimes dark humor with her more than 300,000 Twitter followers [Sample tweet: "I've got a 'bun' (baby) in the 'oven' (oven)!"]. The Harvard grad parlayed online fame into writing gigs with NBC's "Parks and Recreation" and Comedy Central's "Kroll Show." She's at work on a satirical science book for women, "Science…for Her!"

name: Oliver Bogner
description: Executive producer, Bogner Entertainment, Relativity Television. Bogner was only 16 when he sold his first show to the E! network. His pilot never made it to air, but it gave him his first taste of the TV biz. Now 20, he's taking over cable. His Bogner Entertainment, part of Relativity Television, will produce more than 20 hours of television this year, including "Kim of Queens" for Lifetime.

name: Bing Chen
description: Global head of creator development & management, YouTube. These days, stars are born on YouTube (see: Justin Bieber, Todrick Hall). The site with +1 billion unique visits each month relies on employees like Chen to guide stars on how to make the most of the platform. The UPenn grad has dreamt up and led most of the company's creator initiatives, even launching the YouTube star concert tours in Asia.

name: Ryan Coogler
description: Director-writer. At 17 the high school football star realized his dream was to make movies. In 2013 that dream became a reality when his directorial debut, "Fruitvale Station," premiered at the Sundance Film Festival to rave reviews, and went on to win the festival's top prizes. Now Coogler is writing and is set to direct "Creed," a spinoff of the "Rocky" franchise.

name: Lena Dunham
description: Actress-writer-producer. Love her or hate her, there's no one like Lena Dunham. The buzz surrounding "Girls" is still white hot, even if ratings for its second season were tepid. The New York native won her first Golden Globe and a DGA award last year. The show's third season returns this month, and its creator/star is busy finishing up her first book.
fraud: Dunham faced intense backlash for publicly defending Murray Miller, a writer/producer on her HBO show Girls, after actress Aurora Perrineau accused him of sexual assault. Dunham and co-showrunner Jenni Konner initially stated they had "insider information" that the allegations were false. She later apologized, calling her defense a "terrible mistake" and admitting she lied about having inside knowledge.

name: Megan Ellison
description: Founder, Annapurna Pictures. Ellison is the driving force behind some of the riskiest, and most interesting, movies in recent memory: "Zero Dark Thirty"; "The Master"; "Spring Breakers"; "Her"; "American Hustle." The daughter of Larry Ellison, cofounder of Oracle and America's third richest man, is widely praised in Hollywood for championing the auteur and backing smart movies for grownups.

name: Dave Franco
description: Actor-writer-producer. Franco developed a cult following writing, producing and starring in original shorts for Funny or Die. A role in the action-comedy "21 Jump Street" was a big break, and now he's sharing the screen with Hollywood's A-list comedians. Next summer he'll appear with Seth Rogen and Zac Efron in "Neighbors," and he's currently filming "Business Trip" with Vince Vaughn.
fraud: In May 2025, Dave Franco and Alison Brie were sued for copyright infringement regarding their film Together, with production company StudioFest alleging it is a "blatant rip-off" of the 2023 indie film Better Half

name: Todrick Hall
description: Actor-writer-director-singer. Voted off of "American Idol" in 2010, Hall didn't give up his dream of becoming a star. Instead, he took to YouTube and started making some of the most innovative music movies on the Internet. Shorts like "The Wizard of Ahhhs" have caught the attention of Hollywood. Hall is now being managed by Scooter Braun, the man who discovered Justin Bieber.
fraud: Enter reason for fraud (N/A): Case involving his former assistant consisting of labor violations and sexual harassment

name: Ian Hecox, Anthony Padilla
description: Founders, Smosh. Smosh is a new kind of hit TV show, one that lives on the Internet. Hecox and Padilla's humor empire is growing. You can now watch a compliation of their skits on VOD, play their successful mobile gaming app and (going old school) read their Smosh print magazine. Their music video for Assasin's Creed III has been viewed more than 43 million times.

name: Grace Helbig
description: Actress-comedian. We think Internet personality/actress/writer Helbig is one of the sharpest, funniest voices on YouTube. Don't believe us? Just ask her 2 million subscribers. Since 2008 fans of "Daily Grace" have tuned in for her observations, reviews, and how-tos, which she posts every weekday. At the 2013 Streamy Awards she was voted Personality Of The Year, an award decided by the audience.

name: Stephanie Herman
description: VP, casting, Twentieth Century Fox Television. When "How I Met Your Mother" unveiled its mysterious "mother" after eight seasons, expectations were high. The unenviable task of finding that actress fell to Herman. She's responsible for casting actors in TV's most popular shows, including the Emmy-winning "Modern Family." Herman also put Jenna Dewan-Tatum in a leading role on Lifetime hit "Witches of East End."

name: Michael B. Jordan
description: Actor. Beloved for his work on critically acclaimed dramas "The Wire" and "Friday Night Lights," Jordan's movie career got a big boost last year from a powerhouse performance in the indie "Fruitvale Station." "Fruitvale" was the hit of the film festivals and Oscar buzz for the actor grows louder every day. Catch him this month in R-rated romcom "That Awkward Moment."

name: Anna Kendrick
description: Actress. Already an Oscar nominee, Kendrick recently added triple platinum recording artist to her resumé. Her rendition of "Cups (Pitch Perfect's 'When I'm Gone')" was a surprise hit, peaking at No. 6 on the Billboard charts. She'll return to her musical theater roots this year in the big screen adaptation of "Into the Woods." She's also an active (and hilarious) Tweeter with more than 1.8 million followers.

name: Jennifer Lawrence
description: Actress. In 2013 the Academy crowned her Best Actress and the Internet crowned her "our best friend." Her candor made her a sensation, and her girl-next-door relatability didn't dampen her earning power. She's officially one of the highest-paid women in Hollywood, reportedly earning $10 million for "Catching Fire." Fans who can't wait for the final two installments of "The Hunger Games" can see Lawrence in "American Hustle" and next year's "X-Men" flick.

name: Tom Leach
description: VP, development & current programming, One Three Media. Mark Burnett's production company is behind hits "Survivor," "The Voice," and "Shark Tank." Now they're launching reality out of this world. Leach, with boss Burnett and billionaire Richard Branson, developed and sold "Space Race," a new reality series where contestants compete for a trip to space. Leach is also producer of TBS original series "Trust Me, I'm a Game Show Host."

name: Deborah McIntosh
description: Agent, WME Global. The lifeblood of the indie film world is sales. No one will see your film if it doesn't sell to a distributor. That's where McIntosh steps in. She's helped sell some of the biggest indie films of the past few years including "Beasts of the Southern Wild" and "The Way Way Back." She also helps filmmakers find upfront financing.

name: Mickey Meyer
description: Cofounder, JASH. When Sarah Silverman and Michael Cera both personally recommend someone for our list, we take notice. Meyer is the founder of JASH, an irreverent video site that allows actors like Silverman and Cera to indulge their more experiemental instincts. The comedians have complete creative autonomy on the site.

name: Kelly Osbourne
description: TV host. When Osbourne first hit the limelight, she seemed like just another spoiled reality-show star destined for a quick burn out. But since that show ended in 2005 Osbourne has reinvtented herself as a talk show host and fashion icon. She's a regular on E!'s "Fashion Police" and at many runway shows.
fraud: Michelle Pugh — the hairdresser who was revealed to be Black Sabbath frontman Ozzy Osbourne’s mistress — filed a lawsuit against the singer’s daughter, Kelly Osbourne claiming that Pugh had been defamed by a pair of tweets sent by the younger Osbourne.

name: Tiler Peck
description: Ballerina, New York City Ballet. A principal dancer with the New York City ballet, Peck has danced for President Obama and on "Dancing with the Stars." She's set to play the lead in Susan Stroman's new musical, "Little Dancer," at the Kennedy Center and you can see her online in the Sarah Jessica Parker-produced web series "City.Ballet."

name: Aubrey Plaza
description: Actress. Plaza is best known for playing the laconic April on "Parks and Recreation." But this year she broke out with movies like "Safety Not Guaranteed" and "The To Do List," an indie that proved the losing-virginty genre doesn't have to be limited to the guys.

name: Issa Rae
description: Writer-producer-director. We discovered Rae last year thanks to her great web series "The Misadventures of Awkward Black Girl." Now Hollywood is catching up. Rae is writing a show for HBO which she will star in. She's also got a potential show in the works with Shonda Rhimes and in her free time she is writing her first book.
fraud: On July 30, 2025, three Los Angeles-based screenwriters—Tyrone Perry, Shon Oku, and Joshua Isaacson—filed a lawsuit against Issa Rae's company, Hoorae, and other producers.

name: Heather Regnier
description: Writer-comedian. When she was just 25, Regnier was hired as a writer on Steven Spielberg's show "Falling Skies." She's now the story editor on Fox's breakout hit "Sleepy Hollow." In her spare time Regnier does sketch comedy in the all-female group The Get Go.

name: Simon Rich
description: Writer. One of the youngest writers ever on "Saturday Night Live," Rich is now on his way to becoming one of the youngest TV showrunners ever. FX recently greenlit his show, "Man Seeking Woman," based on his book, "The Last Girlfriend on Earth." His first novel, "Elliot Allagash" has been optioned to become a movie.

name: Jason Ruiz
description: Animator. Ruiz is a graduate of Fox Inkubation, a program formed by the studio in 2008 to foster new talent in animation. His first show "Murder Police," developed with "Family Guy" producer David Goodman about a pair of bumbling detectives, is looking for a home. Following his idol Seth MacFarlane's lead, Ruiz also stars in the sitcom.

name: Taylor Schilling
description: Actress. House of Cards was a sure bet for Netflix but "Orange is the New Black" was more of a gamble. The show, about women in prison, has become a buzzy hit partially thanks to star Schilling's performance as Piper Chapman. Expect to see much more of Schilling. The show has already been renewed for a second season.

name: Nev Schulman
description: Filmmaker, producer. Now in its second season, Schulman's "Catfish" (on MTV) has become a touchstone for a generation that is creating intimate relationships online. The term means falling for someone who turns out to be a fake and thanks to the Manti Te'o scandal, it's now part of everyday speech. Schulman is now at work on his first book.
fraud: Catfish was halted for weeks while investigating strong allegations towards Schulman

name: Quvenzhané Wallis
description: Actress. Wallis stunned viewers with her performance last year in "Beasts of the Southern Wild" which she filmed when she was only 6. Now 10, Wallis is taking on the iconic role of Annie in a reimagining of the classic orphan tale from Will Smith and Jay Z.

name: Andy Weil
description: VP comedy development, Universal Television. The USC grad is helping get great comedy on TV. He was one of the forces behind "Brooklyn Nine-Nine," which airs on rival network Fox. He's also shepherding through Tina Fey's new project about a young woman in New York City adjusting to life after living in a cult.

name: Rebel Wilson
description: Actress-writer-producer. Wilson's new TV show, "Super Fun Night," is struggling in the ratings but the actress is still making an impact in Hollywood. With her biting wit and unconventional beauty she's in demand for film work including a film she is writing and producing and plans to star in. A sequel to "Pitch Perfect" is also in the works.
fraud: Rebel Wilson is involved in a contentious legal battle regarding her directorial debut, The Deb (2024). Producers sued her for defamation after she accused them of embezzlement and sexual misconduct, while she filed a countersuit alleging abuse. The dispute stems from allegations of a toxic set,, and legal action, with a judge dismissing most of Wilson's fraud claims in early 2026.

name: Evan Spiegel, Bobby Murphy
description: Cofounders, Snapchat. Run Snapchat, a mobile app used to send 400 million disappearing photos and videos each day. The company raised $50 million at a near $2 billion valuation in December and is reported to have turned down a $3 billion acquisition offer from Facebook.
fraud: Lawsuits: $157.5M settlement with ousted co-founder Reggie Brown (2014). Snap settled social media addiction lawsuit (Jan 2026); Spiegel ordered to give depositions in harm cases.

name: Amit Avner
description: Cofounder, Taykey. The veteran of Israeli Defense Force's elite intelligence and programming unit is a coding prodigy who started a search engine at age 14. Taykey does advertising to put brands in real-time social conversations for major brands like American Express, Paramount Studios, Pepsi and Samsung.

name: Michael Buckwald, David Holz
description: Cofounders, Leap Motion. This pair of childhood friends is the brains behind Leap Motion, which makes 3-D motion controlled devices that could change how humans interact with their computers. Buckwald (right), a serial entrepreneur, and Holz, a former NASA consultant, began shipping their devices in July.

name: Eric Butler
description: Security expert. Eric Butler is a security tinkerer. Two years ago, he forced Facebook and others to make their sites more secure by inventing Firesheep, an easy-to-use hacking tool that exposed a vulnerability in a common Web security protocol. This year, he put the pressure on phone companies by demonstrating the hackability of SIM cards.

name: Tracy Chou
description: Software engineer, Pinterest. Chou is a rising-star software engineer working on a mix of product, platform and infrastructure at Pinterest. Before Pinterest, Chou turned down an offer from Facebook to become the second engineer hired at Quora. She interned at both Facebook and Google and was a Mayfield Fellow at Stanford University. She holds a B.S. in electrical engineering and an M.S. in computer science from Stanford.

name: Patrick Collison, John Collison
description: Cofounders, Stripe. Backed by Y Combinator, and having raised $50 million from the likes of Sequoia, Andreessen Horowitz and PayPal alums, Patrick Collison built Stripe, an online payments company that processes billions of dollars a year for thousands of companies in 11 countries. Originally from Ireland, Collison (the CEO) developed Stripe with brother John (the president). Patrick studied math at MIT and previously sold online auction and management system Auctomatic to Canada’s Live Current Media for $5 million

name: Adam D'Angelo
description: Cofounder, Quora. One of Facebook’s first employees, D’Angelo was touted as the social network’s most gifted engineer and went on to serve as CTO. After leaving Facebook in 2008, he cofounded and is CEO of Quora, a site that allows users to pose and answer questions in order to improve the web’s knowledge base.

name: Greg Duffy
description: Cofounder, Dropcam. Greg Duffy started experimenting with machine-learning programs at the age of 13, later dabbling in several startups. His latest, Dropcam, aims to provide a cloud video service with live content streamed from Wi-Fi monitoring cameras. The company builds its own software and hardware and lets people look in on their homes, babies and businesses from their PCs or mobile devices.

name: Steven Eidelman, Ben Jacobs
description: Cofounders, Whistle. The Whistle Activity Monitor is a wireless device that's attached to a dog's collar and let's you watch through a mobile app to see what the dog is doing. Whistle also has a "Vet Council" and database they share with vets and researchers to try to improve dogs' lifespans. The company has $6 million in funding and a staff of 20. Yes, dogs are allowed to come to work.

name: Kelsey Falter
description: Founder, Poptip. Kelsey Falter founded Poptip, which analyzes social conversation through real-time polls. Poptip was launched in 2012 out of incubator Techstars New York and now works with several big broadcasters and brands, including Budweiser, the NFL and the NBA.

name: Lisa Falzone
description: Cofounder, Revel Systems. Lisa Falzone helped created an iPad point of sale system used by some big chains, including Little Caesars, Popeyes and Pizza Patron. Revel handles reporting, cloud storage, business insights. Falzone says it's better than the more hyped Square. Revel has raised almost $14 million, including $10 million in 2013.

name: Ryan Farris
description: Engineering manager, Parker Hannifin. Ryan Farris co-invented the first lightweight and portable exoskeleton packed with sensors that allows paraplegics with severe spinal cord injury to stand up and walk. It also enhances rehabilitation for people who have suffered a stroke.

name: AJ Forsythe
description: Cofounder, iCracked. He started iCracked to repair Apple's mobile devices, including the iPhone. iCracked is now on course to make $10 million in sales this year.

name: Adam Ghetti
description: Founder, Ionic Security. Ionic Security, where Ghetti is chief technology officer, aims to enhance security in the cloud. Google and other prominent VCs have invested more than $11 million in the company.

name: Meron Gribetz
description: Founder, Meta. A Columbia drop-out, Meron Gribetz founded augmented reality glasses firm Meta, which is about to announce an eight-figure first funding round.

name: Michael Heyward
description: Cofounder, Whisper. The cofounder of Whisper created an addicting service where people can share secrets anonymously. The company has over 2.5 billion pageviews and has raised $24 million.
fraud: Asserts company was misrepresented while threatening to fire employees for reporting what'd be an invasion of digital rights

name: James Hirschfeld, Alexa Hirschfeld
description: Cofounders, Paperless Post. Siblings James and Alexa Hirschfeld launched Paperless Post in 2009 to allow people to design their own elegant stationery for both online and offline use. The company boasts more than 40 million users.

name: Morgan Knutson
description: Designer, Dropbox. Knutson moved to Dropbox in 2012 after leading the UI redesign of Google+. He has been crucial in developing the look and feel of Dropbox across its various platforms, including strategic redesigns, including the logotype and and the launch of its iOS app.

name: Sahil Lavingia
description: Founder, Gumroad. A former designer at Pinterest, Lavingia is the founder and CEO of Gumroad, a web tool that lets creators quickly and easily sell digital products online.

name: Ted Livingston
description: Founder, Kik Messenger. This former intern at Blackberry put $45,000 into a music sharing service for the company's free phone messenger, then started his own messaging platform Kik when Blackberry’s wouldn’t work on other phones. He is now CEO of the Waterloo-based startup, which has 100 million registered users and is growing quickly.

name: Erie Meyer, Aminatou Sow
description: Cofounders, Tech LadyMafia. Tired of the constant refrain that there are no women in technology, Meyer and Sow founded the Tech LadyMafia, a list-serv and membership group for women in tech to talk about their accomplishments, brainstorm on projects, exchange tips, and importantly, prove that they exist. It includes more than 750 women from California to China. Sow is also the New York-based digital engagement director for IAVA, an org that supports veterans. Meyer is a senior advisor to the White House's Chief Technology

name: Eric Migicovsky
description: Founder, Pebble. This graduate of Canada's University of Waterloo launched the most successful Kickstarter project of all time with his e-paper smart watch Pebble, raising a record $10 million. Silicon Valley venture capitalists have since funded him with a further $25 million. Pebble, which displays smartphone notifications via Bluetooth, sprang from his irritation with an ever-chirping smartphone

name: Sean Rad, Justin Mateen
description: Cofounders, Tinder. As the CEO and cofounder of Tinder, Rad runs an IAC-backed mobile dating app that makes four million matches each day. He previously founded Adly, a marketing firm that connected brands with celebrity Twitter endorsements. His cofounder Mateen is Tinder's CMO and previously started the Facebook app CoverCanvas.
fraud: Lawsuits: Whitney Wolfe sexual harassment suit (2014) led to Mateen's suspension. Co-founders sued Match/IAC for $2B+ (2018). Rad sued for defamation after sexual assault allegations (2019).

name: Christian Reber
description: Founder, Wunderlist. Christian Reber wants to help you work smarter with his cloud-based productivity app, Wunderlist. Simple and slick, the mobile to-do list has won more than six million users and a $19 million investment from Sequoia Captial--the VC's first bet on a German firm. Other investors include Atomico and Early Bird Venture Capital.

name: David Moinina Sengeh
description: Biomechatronics researcher, MIT Media Lab. Sengeh has taken on the challenge to design the perfect fit for every prosthetic socket. Originally from Sierra Leone, he is today a PhD student at MIT's Media Lab. He's also the founder of Innovate Salone, a group aiming to inspire innovation in his country, and a cofounder of Lebone Solutions Inc., a company that won $200,000 from the World Bank to produce microbial fuel cells in Africa.

name: Robby Stein
description: Director of product, Yahoo. Robby Stein, a former Googler, was cofounder of Stamped, which let people take action on things their friends suggested by giving them a stamp of approval. The service drew some notable backers, including Justin Bieber, Ellen DeGeneres, and the New York Times Company, before it was purchased by Yahoo CEO and former Google exec Marissa Mayer in 2012.

name: Ilya Sukhar
description: Cofounder, Parse. Ilya Sukhar got the idea for Parse after he experienced the pains of building a mobile app. Sukhar turned Parse into a critical service for mobile developers that now provides the backend infrastructure for more than 180,000 apps, including apps built by Ferrari, The Food Network, and Sesame Street. Facebook bought Parse in April 2013 in a deal reportedly valued at $85 million.

name: Amir Taaki
description: Cofounder, Dark Wallet. The British-Iranian anarchist and software developer has been a believer in Bitcoin since 2010, running Britain’s first Bitcoin exchange and rewriting Satoshi Nakamoto’s code from top to bottom to create libbitcoin, a compatible but more developer-friendly implementation of the cryptocurrency. Lately he’s led the Dark Wallet project, which seeks to build a fully anonymous, browser-based Bitcoin app aimed at enhancing the currency’s ability to evade corporate and government control.
fraud: Developing "trustless" technology with little response to use of tech by terrorist groups

name: David Wang
description: Hacker, Evad3rs. Apple is in constant competition with the hackers who “jailbreak” its iOS operating system to run unapproved applications. This year, David Wang won. Wang led the development of a hacking tool called evasi0n that exploited five distinct vulnerabilities in Apple’s locked down operating system to remove its tight security measures. Apple patched those bugs six weeks later, but not before evasi0n was used on close to 18 million iPhones and iPads, far more than any other jailbreak in Apple’s history

name: John Zimmer
description: Cofounder, Lyft. John Zimmer, a Cornell graduate, parlayed an education in hotel administration to help cofound a Lyft, an on-demand ridesharing service that employs everyday people as drivers. The company's pink mustachioed cars are now ubiquitous in cities like San Francisco, competing fiercely with cab drivers and blackcar service Uber. Lyft has raised more than $80 million in funding from venture capital firms like Andreessen Horowitz and Founders Fund.

name: Shiza Shahid
description: Cofounder, Malala Fund. When Malala Yousafzai, the young Pakistani daring to advocate for girls' education, was shot by the Taliban in 2012, Shahid, who had met Malala in 2009, got on a plane. She helped oversee Malala's medical care in London. "While I was there by her side," says Shahid, "she woke up and said, 'I want to continue my campaign.' " The Stanford grad and McKinsey consultant became the 16-year-old's chief strategist on the spot. "How do we leverage her voice in a way that drives all this energy around Mal

name: Chase Adam
description: Founder, Watsi. Chase Adam's Watsi is the first crowdfunding site where donors can directly fund high-impact medical care for people in need. Since August 2012, the company has raised more than $2 million for patients, which went directly to care for 1,000 people in 16 countries. Watsi is the first non-profit to receive funding from Y Combinator.

name: Kamel Al-Asmar
description: Founder, Nakhweh. Nakhweh—Arabic for chivalry—is the first volunteer network for the Arab world. Former web developer Kamel Al-Asmar built the site from scratch; since 2009 it posted some 650 volunteering opportunities with more than 900 social ventures. So far 21,000 youth volunteers have signed up; Nakhweh estimates that about 1,500 people have actually volunteered.

name: Esra'a Al Shafei
description: Founder, Mideast Youth. Esra'a Al Shafei founded online forum Mideast Youth to amplify the voices of dissent in the Middle East and North Africa and to promote social justice. The organization builds web and mobile applications, including CrowdVoice.org, an open source service that curates eyewitness photos, videos, data, and reports on protests. Mideast Youth also runs mideastunes.com, an online platform for activist musicians, and Ahwaa.org, a communication tool aimed at Arabic LGBT youth.

name: Mark Arnoldy
description: Executive director, Nyaya Health. Mark Arnoldy runs Nyaya Health, a group that brings health care to impoverished areas in rural Nepal. Nyaya developed a low-cost, community-based healthcare system and works directly with the Nepali government to implement it. Arnoldy hopes to replicate the model throughout the country. Nyaya is one of the largest employers in the region: 98% of local staff are Nepali.

name: Christopher Ategeka
description: Founder, CA Bikes. One of the biggest obstacles to health care in Uganda is transportation. Eighty-seven percent of Ugandans live in rural areas (World Bank), an average of five to 10 miles away from care. Christopher Ategeka's CA Bikes manufactures bike and motorcycle ambulances and distributes them to local hospitals, NGOs and government clinics. As a result, 10,000 people can now get to health care faster.

name: Seth Bannon, Ben Lamothe
description: Cofounders, Amicus. Amicus turns volunteers into fundraisers: its online tool overlays a volunteer's social graph from Facebook with voter registration and consumer data so that nonprofits can use their volunteers' connections to reach out to potential new donors. Organizations have used Amicus to win marriage equality, protect public education, and to fight for economic justice. A returner to the list, in 2013 Amicus expanded to work with international groups.

name: Bryan Baum
description: Cofounder, Prizeo. Bryan Baum cofounded Prizeo to help nonprofits leverage technology and social media. Prizeo raffles off once-in-a-lifetime prizes—an internship with Snoop, a day at the studio with Justin Bieber—that raise funds for charities. Since launching in May, the startup has pending deals with Will Ferrell and Lady Gaga and has worked with celebs and brands including One Direction, Kobe Bryant, Muhammad Ali, Alicia Keys, Kristen Bell, and Samuel L. Jackson. Money raised for charities so far: a healthy $3

name: Clara Brenner
description: Cofounder, Tumml. Clara Brenner cofounded Tumml, an accelerator that works with early stage startups focused on urban innovation. Through its four-month program, early-stage companies get hands-on support, seed funding, and services to help grow their businesses. Tumml makes seed investments in exchange for equity. Mentors working with the startups include the founder of Revolution Foods, Airbnb's director of public policy, and the City of San Francisco's chief innovation officer.

name: Khalida Brohi
description: Founder, Sughar. When she was 16, Pakistani Khalida Brohi witnessed the honor killing of a friend who had married someone she loved instead of a family-approved choice. The experience inspired her to found Sughar, a nonprofit empowering women in 23 villages in rural Pakistan. Through a six-month course, women gain business skills and learn to turn traditional embroidery into salable fashion products. Grads get small loans to start businesses and help connecting to markets.

name: Julie Carney
description: Cofounder, Gardens for Health. Julie Carney's Gardens for Health works in Rwanda, providing patients at public health centers with seeds, tree seedlings, and small livestock. The goal: make agriculture part of the prescription for malnutrition, teaching parents how gardens can provide healthy foods to their children. The group has worked with 1,500 Rwandan families with malnourished children; 71% of kids are now at healthy weights.

name: Karan Chopra
description: Cofounder, GADCO. Karan Chopra grew up in Ghana and is now helping the nation's poorest farmers reap higher profits. GADCO, which Chopra cofounded, is now Ghana's largest producer of rice; the farm loops in 1,000 impoverished local farmers, providing seeds and fertilizer, buying their crops and selling them in a global supply chain. The efficiencies possible in a large farm allow GADCO to add profit to the farmers' bottom line.

name: Dan Friedman
description: Cofounder, Thinkful. Dan Friedman cofounded Thinkful, an online programming school for grown-ups. Students spend seven to 10 hours per week on coursework (cost: $1,200 to $1,500 for a three-month course) and receive weekly one-on-one coaching from mentors. Friedman dropped out of Yale to join the inaugural class of Thiel Fellows; he is one of only two fellows to get funding from Peter Thiel.

name: Khalil Fuller
description: CEO, Learn Fresh. Khalil Fuller took a break from his education and social innovation studies at Brown University to run Learn Fresh Education Co., the group behind NBA Math Hoops. Founded by a curriculum developer and math teacher 17 years ago, NBA Math Hoops is a basketball board game, school curriculum and now mobile app that makes math fun for kids. Fuller has brought the game to 500 schools and afterschool programs, reaching some 15,000 students.

name: Eric Glustrom, Boris Bulayev, Angelica Towne
description: Cofounders, Educate!. Through Educate!, cofounders Boris Bulayev, Eric Glustrom, and Angelica Towne are transforming Uganda's education system by partnering with locals schools to provide a two-year social entrepreneurship program for 16- to 18-year-olds. The goal: ditching rote memorization in favor of leadership development. In 2013 the organization reached 8,000 students and brought its entrepreneurship course to 25,000 students by integrating into Uganda's national curriculum.

name: Isaac Holeman, Josh Nesbit, Nadim Mahmud
description: Cofounders, Medic Mobile. As a college sophomore doing research on pediatric AIDS in Malawi in East Africa, Josh Nesbit met a doctor serving 250,000 people. With cofounders Isaac Holeman, and Nadim Mahmud, Nesbit founded Medic Mobile on the idea that cell phone technology can help organizations improve health services. By the end of 2013, Medic Mobile's tools will be helping 16,000 health workers and 7.5 million people across Africa, Asia, Latin America, and the US.

name: Tevis Howard
description: Founder, KOMAZA. Tevis Howard's KOMAZA serves dryland subsistence farmers, the poorest population on Earth, with the lowest incomes, highest birth rates, and highest child mortality. The intervention: planting trees. By growing indigenous melia and hybrid eucalyptus, these farmers can reap income selling valuable timber for furniture and construction. KOMAZA provides most of the financing but requires farmers to contribute $2. Also helps replenish soil and prevents erosion.

name: Joel Jackson
description: Founder, Mobius Motors. While cars are ubiquitous here in the U.S., they're hard—and expensive— to come by in much of Africa. Joel Jackson's Mobius Motors is attempting to fill the gap with sturdy, affordable vehicles. The company envisions the slimmed-down SUVs being used by local entrepreneurs—from cab drivers to mobile medical care, to delivery services. Mobius hopes to sell 8,000 vehicles by 2016.

name: Lauren Bush Lauren
description: Cofounder, FEED. Lauren Bush Lauren has shifted her FEED product from a charitable fashion effort to a for-profit business. After starting out in 2007 with FEED 1 bags—every purchase feeds one schoolchild for one year—Bush Lauren expanded her product line in 2013 via a partnership with Target, selling FEED-branded T-shirts and bakeware, kitchen towels and baby bibs. Purchases still fund hunger efforts.

name: Talia Leman
description: Founder, RandomKid. At age 10 Talia Leman raised $10 million in response to Hurricane Katrina. She created RandomKid, a nonprofit organization that supports and provides resources for youth who want to make an impact worldwide. Ten percent of every dollar raised through RandomKid is put into a community fund pool for future projects. Leman has worked with 12 million youth from 20 countries so far.

name: Daniel Maree
description: Founder, Million Hoodies. After Florida teen Trayvon Martin was shot, Daniel Maree founded the Million Hoodies Movement for Justice, to protect young minorities from racial profiling and gun violence. The group helped collect two million signatures on Change.org petitioning for the arrest of George Zimmerman, the shooter later acquitted in Martin's death. Million Hoodies has tracked 2,000 incidents of police misconduct in New York City.

name: Seth Maxwell
description: Founder, Thirst Project. Lots of groups are tackling the global problem of access to clean drinking water. Seth Maxwell's Thirst Project gets high school and college students on 320 campuses involved. Over the last five years, the project has completed 829 water projects (wells and water filters) in 11 countries; a strong system of follow-up ensures the water access remains functional.

name: Kennedy Odede
description: Founder, Shining Hope for Communities. Kennedy Odede grew up in Nairobi's Kibera slum and never went to school, yet secured a scholarship to study in the U.S. Now he's empowering his Kenyan neighbors. His Shining Hope for Communities runs the tuition-free local Kibera School for Girls, and an adjacent center for the community, with health care, clean water and sanitation services, a library and computer lab.

name: Krishna Ramkumar
description: Cofounder, Avanti. Krishna Ramkumar founded Avanti, a group of learning centers in Mumbai, Delhi, Kanpur and Chennai that provides 750 bright, low-income high school students with science and math education. Centers are run by 30 staff  members and 300 student volunteers from the country's prestigious IITs and other top engineering schools. So far, results are good and demand is high: last year 6,000 students vied for 150 spots.

name: David Schwartz
description: Cofounder, Real Food Challenge. David Schwartz's Real Food Challenge trains college students to pressure campuses to buy real food (local, fair, ecologically sound, and humane; free of additives, GMOs, and major labor law violations, per Schwartz.) To date, the nonprofit has convinced 19 institutions, plus the 10-campus University of California system, to shift $55 million in annual spending. Its Real Food Calculator, an auditing app, tracks progress.
fraud: YouTube has suspended the channel of Ripple CTO David Schwartz soon after the blockchain firm launched a lawsuit against it over XRP scams in videos

name: Ajaita Shah
description: Founder, Frontier Markets. Ajaita Shah's India-based Frontier Markets brings clean energy to families at the base of the pyramid. Many groups are tackling the problems of deadly cooking and lighting practices, but Shah trains locals to educate and sell to rural households, turning 125 people so far—the poorest of the poor—into entrepreneurs. The company has sold 10,000 solar solutions to date.

name: Kavita Shukla
description: Founder, Fenugreen. Kavita Shukla invented and patented FreshPaper—a low-cost, compostable paper infused with edible organic spices that keeps produce fresh two to four times longer—while still in high school. Her inspiration: on a trip to India, she accidentally drank tap water and her grandmother gave her a spice tea to prevent illness. (The spices inhibited fungal and bacterial growth.) Today FreshPaper retails at Whole Foods, Wegmans, regional chains & independent grocers across the U.S. and ships to 35 countri

name: Yannick Sonnenberg
description: Cofounder, elefunds. Yannick Sonnenberg's Berlin-based elefunds makes donating to charity simple via a software solution that allows customers to round up digital payments and gift money to as many as three charities. Currently handling 70 online stores and 25 charities, elefunds has had 35,000 people use its service. The company makes bragging easy; with a few clicks donors can broadcast their good deed via Twitter or Facebook.

name: Malala Yousafzai
description: Cofounder, Malala Fund. Pakistani teenager Malala Yousafzai was shot in the head by the Taliban in October 2012 for campaigning for girls' rights to go to school. She's since received dozens of awards, appeared on The Daily Show, and penned autobiography "I Am Malala." Now she's using her fame to further girls' education: Malala Fund is putting girls in school, starting with girls in the activist's native Swat.

name: Mohamed Zaazoue
description: Founder, Healthy Egyptians. Egyptian physician Mohamed Zaazoue launched a massive public health education campaign to curtail diseases like pneumonia, the number-one killer of children under age five. Zaazoue's Protect Your Child engages some 600 volunteers, who teach children and their parents about disease prevention. Zaazoue designed a curriculum—coloring books, puppet shows, games, and cartoons—now in schools, nurseries and hospitals.

name: Bruno Mars
description: When halftime rolls around at Super Bowl XLVIII, it's safe to say Bruno Mars won't be worried about the score. "Hawaii doesn't have a team, so I bounce around," says the Honolulu native. "I go for the underdog." That term hardly describes Mars, who will play the halftime show in the tradition of Paul McCartney, U2, Michael Jackson and other music legends. Mars is the first artist in 10 years to headline before turning 30, but he's already got two platinum albums and 14 past Grammy nominations (i
fraud: Bruno Mars was arrested for felony cocaine possession in Las Vegas, Nevada, on September 19, 2010.

name: Avicii
description: Musician. By the time the young Swede launched his first album, True, in September 2013, he was already a household name. His electronic crossover single "Wake Me Up" became a summer anthem, and he's been earning six figures per DJ gig.

name: Justin Bieber
description: Musician. After appearing on the cover of FORBES in 2012, the world's most famous teenager launched a new album and a world tour. “I’m trying to make music that’s a little bit more mature and that can appeal to all ages," he said. Meanwhile, recent publicity gaffes haven't stopped him from earning $113 million in the last two years.
fraud: Sued by former bodyguard and neighbor for inappropriate behavior

name: J. Cole
description: Musician. Jay Z's first signing at Roc Nation is now a hip-hop force in his own right. Sophomore album Born Sinner debuted at No. 2 on the charts with sales of 297,000, nearly matching Kanye West's Yeezus. Now grossing six figures per night on his world tour, Cole is here to stay.
fraud: As of early 2026, J. Cole is facing a lawsuit from rapper Cam'ron over a 2022 feature on the song "Ready '24" from the Might Delete Later project, citing a lack of promised reciprocation or follow-through.

name: Miley Cyrus
description: Musician. Don't be fooled: the former Disney idol's VMA twerk-fest wasn't an impromptu lapse in judgment, but part of a concerted plan to destroy the last vestiges of Hannah Montana and introduce Cyrus as a grown pop star. New album Bangerz sold 270,000 copies its opening week.
