By age 19 he'd started Tumblr, the social blogging platform that he would end up selling to Yahoo for $1.1 billion in 2013. An $81 million bonus package will likely keep him at the company for the next three years.

name: Ezra Klein
description: Columnist, Washington Post. Klein is one of the best-known and most widely read columnists at the Washington Post and has been since he joined the paper in 2009. He's been blogging about politics since 2003, and is also a frequent on-air presence on MSNBC. The left-leaning Klein is also a columnist for Bloomberg View.

name: Dan Koh
description: General manager, HuffPost Live. As Arianna Huffington's chief of staff, Koh helped keep a 700-person news organization with seven international editions running smoothly. Now he does the same at HuffPost Live, the ambitious interactive internet TV venture launched in 2012. Before joining HuffPost, he served as an advisor to Boston mayor Thomas Menino.

name: Chris Lavergne, Alex Magnin
description: Founder, COO, Thought Catalog. Founded in 2010 by CEO Lavergne (right), a former Wall Street consultant, Thought Catalog thinks of itself as an experimental media collective. Millennial earnestness is the dominant tone of the essays it publishes, which can be confessional, political or just silly. All viewpoints are welcomed; no observation is too jejune. Magnin is the architect of Thought Catalog's ad sales strategy.

name: Libby Leffler
description: Strategic partnerships manager, Facebook. Leffler is the point person on Facebook's partnerships with media organizations, nonprofits, world leaders, executives and other important entities. Her past roles at the company include service as co-anchor of the streaming video presentation "Facebook Live" and assisting Sheryl Sandberg as her business lead, managing the "Lean In" author's public appearances and other projects. Like Sandberg, she's a Google veteran.

name: Uzoamaka Maduka
description: Cofounder, The American Reader. Maduka is a mix of modern and throwback: A child of Nigerian immigrants and Princeton graduate, she decided to start a literary magazine, in print, at a time when most of her classmates were dreaming of launching hit apps. There's a daily website, too, and a partnership with Salon.com helps with digital distribution.

name: Claire Mazur
description: Cofounder, Of A Kind. Mazur and her cofounder, Erica Cerulo, were early to the trend of integrating content and commerce around fashion. Of A Kind, which they started in 2010, helps emerging designers sell their wares by bringing the stories behind them to life. Despite never having raised venture capital, the site is already generating seven-figure sales.

name: Brit Morin
description: Founder, Brit + Co. The closest thing Silicon Valley has to a Martha Stewart, Morin uses YouTube videos and other digital media channels to inspire people to take up arts and crafts. The "Brit Kits" she sells take some of the "Y" out of "DIY." A veteran of Apple and Google, she's married to Path founder Dave Morin.

name: Matt Mullenweg
description: Founder, Automattic. In a classic entrepreneurship story, Mullenweg created Wordpress to satisfy his own need for a better blogging tool. A true believer in the open-source philosophy, he has largely resisted pressure to commercialize his creation, which powers one in six blogs. An enterprise version provides the revenues that keep his company running and his investors happy.
fraud: WP Engine sued Automattic and Mullenweg for abuse of power, attempted extortion, and libel. Mullenweg took, then retracted, hostile actions against WP Engine.

name: Carolyn Penner
description: Head of product communications, Twitter. As Twitter's chief spokesperson on the product side during the run-up to its massive IPO, Penner has been holding down what's arguably one of the most high-profile communications jobs in American business. She thrives under the microscope, having previously handled public affairs at Google.

name: Tiffany Pham
description: Director of business development, strategic initiatives and partnerships, CBS. Pham has a long title and an even longer resume: A Harvard Business School grad, she handles partnerships and strategic initiaitives for more than 150 digital assets at CBS while also producing documentaries and feature films and acting as head of marketing for the Beijng International Screenwriting Competition. She also wrote a book about business strategy and information technology.

name: Olenka Polak
description: Cofounder, MyLingo. Olenka's upbringing in a Polish-speaking household gave her the idea for a service that would allow viewers to watch movies and TV shows in English while hearing real-time translations. Her concept won the 2013 Harvard Innovation Challenge and attracted attention from investors. Polak dropped out of Harvard to pursue MyLingo full time.

name: Sterling Proffer
description: Director of platform, Vice. Proffer is the man in charge of fast-growing Vice Media's digital distribution and strategy. A Vice employee right out of college, he helped the company win funding from Google to launch its YouTube channels, which have millions of subscribers and have produced half a billion views. He also launched Vice's technology vertical, Motherboard.

name: Rachel Rosenfelt
description: Cofounder, The New Inquiry. As a freshman at Barnard, Rosenfelt secured a coveted internship at The New Yorker. But instead of grasp the bottom rung of the ladder, she and two friends created The New Inquiry, an outlet for young writers who, like her, find their creative aspirations frustrated by the dwindling of old media.The New Inquiry is digital-only, supported by subscriptions and live events.

name: Melissa Rosenthal
description: Director of creative services, Buzzfeed. Native advertising is the focus of Buzzfeed's revenue strategy, and perhaps the most important trend in the media business. Rosenthal oversees a 40-person team that produces native ads that readers read and share just like articles -- in theory, at least. Rosenthal established BuzzFeed's creative department and is now helping recreate it in other countries.

name: Callie Schweitzer
description: Director of digital innovation, Time. Building an "innovation hub" at the Time Inc. newsweekly, Schweitzer serves as the pivot point between editorial, business and marketing. A champion networker online and off, she was previously head of marketing at Vox Media and deputy publisher at Talking Points Memo. She has the media business in her blood: Her father is George Schweitzer, longtime head of marketing for CBS.

name: Nikhil Sethi, Garrett Ullom
description: Cofounders, Adaptly. Sethi (right) and Ullom have been friends since they met in a classroom at Northwestern University. (The course: Probability of Statistics in Random Signals.) Adaptly is their solution for advertisers who are overwhelmed by the challenges of managing their campaigns across numerous social platforms. They developed the idea in an incubator program sponsored by DreamIt Ventures.

name: Shane Snow
description: Cofounder, Contently. Former journalist who cofounded (along with two friends) a company to take advantage of rise of branded content. Launched out of TechStars NY, Contently now has a network of more than 25,000 freelancers. It has 24 full time employees and has raised $3 million in funding.

name: Jason Stein
description: Founder, Laundry Service. Stein's Laundry Service sits at the intersection of social media marketing and branded content. Just two years in, it already has more than 30 employees in New York and Los Angeles. Fun fact: Stein solicited his first client with a Craigslist ad. Amazon, Disney and the Jones Group have since followed.

name: Brian Stelter
description: Host, Reliable Sources, CNN. After covering the TV news business since he was in college, Stelter is now a part of it, having won a bake-off to become the new host of "Reliable Sources," CNN's weekly press criticism show. His blog TV Newser led to a job at The New York Times, from which perch he published "Top of the Morning," a bestselling nonfiction book about the morning TV wars.
fraud: Lawyer Lin Wood accused Stelter and other CNN employees of "breach of confidentiality" regarding tweets about defamation cases against the network, particularly following the settlement of the lawsuit brought by Covington Catholic student Nicholas Sandmann.

name: Eric Stromberg
description: Cofounder, Oyster. Whether you liken it to Netflix or Spotify, Oyster is trying to introduce to the book business the same all-you-can-eat consumption that's proven popular in other parts of the digital media world. Peter Thiel's Founders Fund led its most recent venture round. Stromberg worked in business development at Hunch, leaving shortly after it was acquired by eBay.

name: Fernando Vila
description: VP of programming, Fusion. A Miami native, Vila is helping Disney's ABC build its way into the U.S. Hispanic market with Fusion, the English-language news network it launched in 2013 in partnership with Univision. Before joining Univision in 2011, he cofounded the Americas Business Council Foundation.

name: Brian Wong
description: Cofounder, Kiip. Imagine you just posted a 5-mile run to the RunKeeper app when an ad on your iPhone pops up offering you a free liter of Propel Water. Or you just finished a particularly fiendish level of Candy Crush and you are offered free Sour Patch Kids as a reward. These "moments of achievement" and "serendipitous rewards" are a big part of the future of advertising, at least according to Wong, who cofounded Kiip in 2010, a year after graduating from the University of British Columbia at age 17. "We track
fraud: Brian Wong, the co-founder and former CEO of the mobile advertising startup Kiip, was involved in a significant sexual assault controversy that began with a 2019 indictment and concluded with a plea deal in 2024.

name: Katrina Bekessy
description: Director of technology & design, R/GA. Part technologist, part designer, Bekessy is a Parsons grad and interaction-design specialist at R/GA, a digital agency, handling technical strategy and implementation across channels--websites, social, mobile, and enterprise-level systems. She has worked on projects for clients such as Walmart and McCormick, and leads the technology department in R/GA’s Austin/Southwest region.

name: Mallory Blair
description: Cofounder, Small Girls PR. Cofounded a PR firm that prioritizes personable media relations. Since starting three years ago, the firm has become the agency of record for technology companies such as GE and Meetup as well as the promotional arm for media companies like Flavorpill and Gawker. It has never used a wire, rarely writes press releases, and never sends blanket pitches, relying instead on creative partnerships with bloggers and founders.

name: Derek Blais
description: Senior art director, BBDO Canada. In his nine years of experience, Blais has created digital, social and branded-content campaigns for brands such as Heineken and PepsiCo. His work has garnered awards from the Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity, Effies, The One Show and Webby Awards, among others. A McDonald's campaign, "Our Food. Your Questions," recently won nine Golds and Best In Show at the Canadian Marketing Association Awards. He has been shortlisted as a "Marketer on The Rise" nominee by the American Market

name: Raymond Braun
description: LGBT marketing lead, Google/YouTube. Also associate product marketing manager, YouTube Entertainment Marketing, Braun originated and led YouTube’s first-ever marketing campaign, #ProudToLove, dedicated to celebrating the LGBT community, which involved turning the YouTube logo rainbow. The campaign has won marketing awards and been widely praised by LGBT thought leaders and influencers. Leads global LGBT marketing initiatives and community outreach for YouTube/Google.

name: Victor Cheng, Roger Lee
description: Cofounders, PaperG. Cofounded PaperG, a company whose technology can automatically create and distribute display ads across platforms and devices -- lowering the cost of online advertising for small- and medium-sized businesses. PaperG has been named one of Forbes’ 100 Most Promising Companies in America. Clients include Hearst, Time Warner Cable, Charter Communications, and Tribune.

name: Katrina Craigwell
description: Global manager of digital marketing, GE. Leads content for the digital marketing team at General Electric. Drives content creation and distribution across GE.com, Txchnologist.com and GE's corporate properties internationally, as well as GE's social-media presences on platforms including Instagram, Tumblr and YouTube. Has spent the last two-and-a-half years at GE bringing the company's technology to life via visual content. In November 2013, she began a two-month assignment in Dubai, working with the GE MENAT team on digital brand stra

name: David Dinetz, Dylan Trussell, Colt Seman
description: Cofounders, Culprit Creative. Cofounded an agency that specializes in brand storytelling. Clients include King, makers of the Candy Crush app, and Legendary Pictures, the makers of the Dark Knight Trilogy and Inception. The agency is currently pitching Tesla. Dinetz was previously director of production at Ignition Creative, where he helped spearhead the Tomb Raider video game campaign. Trussell has been Dinetz's creative partner since college; he directed commercials for brands such as ESPN and Mattel. Seman is a cinematogr

name: Andrew Dumont
description: Director of business development, Moz. At Moz, a marketing analytics platform with more than 25,000 clients such as Disney, FedEx, Starbucks and Boeing, Dumont is responsible for business development, overseeing a team responsible for growth initiatives such as data licensing, product distribution and strategic partnerships. He created the company’s product distribution channel; it now accounts for more than 4% of total revenue, which was $27 million in 2013. Previously he was a cocreator at Stride and director of business developmen

name: Whitney Fishman
description: Tech and consumer insights director, MEC. Since joining MEC in 2013, Fishman has developed new client communication tools, helped launch the agency’s innovation initiative and revamped the agency’s thought leadership program. She oversees the creation of proprietary educational materials for clients. She previously held positions at MediaVest, Grey and Buzz Marketing Group. Fishman also cofounded Summer Air Records in 2004, an independent music label specializing in artist relations, public relations and marketing, and is a founding boa

name: Teddy Goff
description: Cofounder, Precision Strategies. Former digital director for Obama For America, where he oversaw a team of more than 200 people nationwide managing the campaign's social media, email, web, online advertising, online organizing, design, front-end and product development, design, and video strategies. At Precision Strategies, he is applying expertise in digital, communications, and data and analytics to the private sector. Clients include The Mark Cuban Cos., Microsoft and the Democratic National Committee.

name: Rich Greco
description: Head of design, Droga5. Greco heads design at this creative and strategic agency, overseeing a staff of eight designers. He has been working professionally since 2007 and previously worked at MTV, Lowe New York and Deutsch Inc. Droga5 clients include Prudential, American Express, The Coca-Cola Co., Motorola, Under Armour, Mondelez International, Chobani, Spotify and UNICEF. He was cited as one of Business Insider’s 30 Most Creative People in Advertising Under 30.

name: Jack Hanlon
description: Cofounder, Kinetic Social. Also head of product, Hanlon is the architect of the data-focused Kinetic Social tech platform, which helps marketers and their agencies manage campaigns across social platforms and also gain an understanding of their audiences. The company's more than 500 clients since launch include Mars, H&M and Victoria's Secret's PINK. In one quarter he increased profitability from 19% to 53% while growing the client portfolio.

name: Amy Karr
description: Experience designer, Starcom MediaVest Group. In her role at media agency Starcom MediaVest Group, Karr was a part of the Experience Design team, a group that has now become Zero Dot, a brand experience consulting group that launched in 2013, of which Karr was cofounder and first employee. Karr devises unique, innovative media ideas and strategies that are inherently designed for the digital age, across multiple screens—highly social and participatory.

name: Joanna Kennedy
description: Senior social media specialist, RPA. Kennedy has helped shape notable, in some cases award-winning, social campaigns for RPA clients including Honda and Intuit--such as the teaser for Honda’s “Matthew’s Day Off” Super Bowl ad. She also drove the seeding strategy for the award-winning (and Cannes Lions International Festival of Creatity-shortlisted) video to promote the Newport Beach Film Festival. Works closely with the agency’s creative, technology and media teams.

name: Greg Kimball
description: Manager of digital strategy and communications, L'Oréal. Tasked with overhauling the digital and social properties of L'Oreal USA, Kimball currently is working on relaunching the corporate website and implementing the corporate team's first social strategy over the next year. He is the winner of a Young Guns Award at L'Oreal.

name: Jack Krawczyk
description: Director of product management, Pandora. Krawczyk leads the product-technology team, covering all advertising products at Pandora that are responsible for more than 80% of company revenue. He was previously head of monetization and publisher products at StumbleUpon; there he launched Paid Discovery, a platform enabling brands to maximize the reach of their produced content. Before that, he was product marketing manager at Google, where he was on the founding team that developed Google+. He has written extensively on native advertising,

name: Michael Kuzmich
description: Associate director of motion graphics, Firstborn. Kuzmich works at Firstborn, a digital advertising agency with clients such as PepsiCo, L’Oreal, Google and Sony that has produced award-winning work. He specializes in motion graphics, 2D and 3D animation, 3D Studio Max, Autodesk Maya, Photoshop, After Effects, video post-production and  Flash animation. Previously he was an interactive designer and animator at BEAM Interactive.

name: Douglas Lusted
description: Cofounder, WestonExpressions. Lusted founded WestonExpressions, a technology corporation providing hardware and software innovations for the out-of-home advertisement industry, after winning the University of Waterloo’s Innovation Showcase and VeloCity Venture Fund in his second year of business and environment studies. That lead to the development of Linkett technology. Linkett is a small device that enables digital screens to collect data about passing consumers and optimize the digital content toward their demographic.

name: Jeff MacDonald
description: Creative technologist, The Martin Agency. A creative technologist at The Martin Agency, during the school year MacDonald is an adjunct professor at the VCU Brandcenter, as well as the marketing adviser for Feast RVA. During his first year at grad school he co-led creative-technologist classmates in building a website for organizing panel discussions at the 2011 SXSW interactive festival; the site became Panelizr and went from concept to beta in 10 days.

name: Charles Merritt
description: Partner, 80amps. Partner at 80amps, a company that assists startups by providing a combination of seed capital and professional services in exchange for a stake in the company. He has implemented marketing strategies at Kayak.com and Jetsetter.com that fueled growth at each firm. He has also served as a video producer, managing video journalists for an online media startup.

name: Mitch Orkis
description: Director of client development, Vizeum US. At Vizeum, a media agency that is part of Dentsu Aegis and launched in the U.S. in 2011, his role has been to help spur new business growth, which has increased approximately 30% in 18 months. Clients include Pernod Ricard, Seventh Generation, Sonos, and Dow Jones. Awards include 20th Century Fox, Prometheus: Winner of Gold for Media Innovation and Silver for Media Creativity at the Media Week Awards 2012.

name: Khoa Phan
description: Freelance Vine animator. Tapped by notable brands such as Peanuts Worldwide, Snapple, Swiffer, MTV, (RED) and Livestrong to create extremely fluid, storytelling stop-motion videos on Vine. His work has been covered by CNN and Bloomberg TV. Shortlist finalist at Tribeca Film Fest 2013 and Mashable’s Most Creative Stop-Motion Animator.

name: Matthew Rubinger
description: Director of luxury accessories, Heritage Auctions. Rubinger was hired three years ago at a six-figure salary to launch the luxury accessories division of Heritage Auctions — the third largest auctioneer of collectibles in the world and the largest based in the United States. When Rubinger came on board straight out of college, he had never run an auction before. He’s now in charge of three sales a year that together brought in $9 million last year.

name: Maude Standish
description: Cofounder, Tarot. Cofounded a company called Tarot, a Millennial trend insight company and sister company to Mistress Creative, an agency based in Venice, CA. Is also the directory of strategy at Mistress Social, the social division of Mistress Creative that translates the latest trends into social campaigns. Standish is the former executive director at Trendera and writes for Vice, The Huffington Post and Agency Spy. She will be speaking at SXSW this year about the impact the economy of sharing is having on our

name: Rachel Tipograph
description: Global director of digital and social media, Gap. A former strategist at Undercurrent, a digital strategy firm, working with marketers such as PepsiCo, Levi’s and Disney. She also is an angel investor and adviser to early-stage ad-tech and consumer-goods start-ups. Previously, she was a “reverse mentor” at Time Warner, teaching senior executives about social media. She's been a speaker at SXSW, Internet Week and The Corporate Social Media Summit. Under her guidance Gap purchased all mobile ads on Tumblr for a 24-hour time period as part of a pr

name: Elliott Wiener
description: Director of consumer insights, Razorfish. Wiener has experience in A/B and multivariate testing, statistical modeling such as regression analysis and factor analysis, cookie-level media and site-side analysis, survey analysis, media-mix modeling, match-market testing, mobile, and social ROI analysis. In addition, he is certified in Google Analytics, Adobe Analytics products, Unica, Webtrends, Coremetrics, Flurry Mobile Analytics, Atlas, Dart DFA, SQL, SPSS, SAS, and other specialty and web analytics software. Prior to joining Razorfish,

name: Farryn Weiner
description: Global director of digital and social communications, Michael Kors Worldwide. Weiner heads global social strategy for fashion brand Michael Kors Worldwide, overseeing social, editorial and digital marketing and media strategy. She led the development of the first Instagram ad ever, which ran in November. Weiner previously headed up social media, editorial content and marketing strategy for Jetsetter.com at Gilt Groupe. She's been a panelist at SXSW, Internet Week, Social Media Week and Luxury Daily Conference, among others. Accolades include Top 10 Most Stylish Social Med

name: Elyse Winer
description: Marketing and communications manager, MC10 Inc. In just over a year, Winer developed a new, stronger brand identity for MC10, a venture-backed wearable electronics startup. Her work as brand ambassador and product-marketing head led to the successful launch last year of MC10’s first commercial product, the Reebok Checklight, which monitors physical data and gauges head impact of on-field athletes. She has appeared on Fox and Friends and has been quoted in the Boston Globe, among other media outlets, discussing the product and increasing the p

name: Pranav Yadav
description: CEO, Neuro-Insight. After winning the Starr Scholarship (full ride, given to six kids from Asia) to go to Carleton College, India-born Yadav graduated magna cum laude with three majors, then went to Goldman Sachs, where he worked as a sales trader for structured equity derivatives. Left to work for ReD Associates, an innovation strategy consulting firm. He was later introduced to Dr. Richard Silberstein, inventor of Neuro-Insight’s technology, who offered him the position of CEO. Neuro-Insight is a neuromarketing f

name: Carter Cleveland
description: Founder and CEO, Artsy. When Carter Cleveland was a Princeton computer science student back in 2008, he went online searching for a picture to decorate his dorm room. "I assumed there would be a website with all the world's art on it," he recalls. There wasn't. So he set out to build one, with a Pandora-like feature that recommends artists to users. His company, Artsy, displays more than 85,000 pieces of art from 400 foundations and museums (including the National Gallery of Art and the Getty) and 1,400 galleries. Thou

name: Ahmed Abdelrahman
description: Fashion designer, Thamanyah. Born in the United Arab Emirates, Abdelrahman designs androgynous clothes under the name Thamanyah, which means "eight" in Arabic, inspired by his eight siblings and the eight-pointed star that symbolizes the eight gates of heaven used in Islamic art and architecture. His signature creation is a kandora, a traditional, ankle-length Middle-Eastern men's garment. He also designs funnel-necked coats, shirts with a dervish collar, loose-fitting, sculptural jackets.

name: Jensen Adoni
description: Shoemaker, Modern Vice. Founders of Modern Vice shoewear, Jensen and his brother, Jordan, make shoes in midtown Manhattan for national and international retailers. They started their business after their father, a former cobbler, left the trade. The shoes reflect a downtown edge and are often the product of designer collaborations; they're sold in Lord & Taylor, Urban Outfitters, and Macy's, among others.
fraud: Legal documents (e.g., von Nolde v. Austin Coins, Inc. et al., 2024) have alleged that Jensen Adoni and others participated in a, "massive coin fraud operation" involving telemarketing scams, the sale of overvalued coins, and the conversion of customer assets.

name: Rosie Assoulin
description: Fashion designer. Assoulin uses rich Italian fabrics to make contemporary twists on American classics. Her debut collection for 2014 includes pantsuits in neutrals like beige, white and black; she accents one black outfit with an oversized gold sash and mixes basics like fitted jackets and drawstring pants with draped asymmetrical dresses.

name: Michelle Campbell
description: Jewelry designer. Launched in 2011, Campbell's collection is sold around the world and has been featured in Vogue, Bazaar, Elle and The New York Times. The looks pull from both natural and manmade surroundings, architecture and an urban city grid. It has a downtown gotham look and feel.

name: Ian Collings
description: Industrial designer, Fort Standard. Together with Gregory Buntain, 30, Collings founded industrial design firm which crafts everything from lighting and furniture like tables, stools and bookcases, to bowls, candelabras and coat hooks. Its products, made of materials like ceramic, wood and bronze, have clean, simple lines. Clients include Warby Parker and All-Clad.

name: Asher Dunn
description: Furniture designer, Studio Dunn. When he was 18 months old Dunn used his Sesame Street screwdriver set to dismantle the ventilation system in his childhood home. Since then he has been fascinated with putting things together. His Studio Dunn in Providence, RI, produces sleek, simple furniture, lighting, bowls and vases that recall mid-20th century modernism. He also founded Keeseh Woodshop, a community workshop that teaches woodworking, and Anchor Providence, an arts and business incubator.

name: Alan Eckstein
description: Design director, Timo Weiland. The men's and women's line features sportswear mixed with sharp but casual suits and feminine, romantic pieces. Founded in 2009 along with creative director Timo Weiland (30), the label was nominated for the Ecco Domani award for women's and men's collections, with the duo later selected to sit on the Council of Fashion Designers of America's Fashion Incubator program. Clothing stocked by Barneys, Pas De Deux, Los Angeles's Satine, and top retailers in Japan.

name: Crystal Ellis, Stephanie Beamer
description: Furniture designers, Egg Collective. Ellis and Beamer are part of a design trio that includes Hillary Petrie, 30. They met as freshmen at Washington University in St. Louis and in 2011, founded furniture design studio Egg Collective, which makes tables, chairs, cabinets, lighting out of organic materials like wood, glass, brass and a mineral called travertine. Their pieces have clean, functional lines with a contemporary edge.Their latest commission: a seating area for New York City Ballet-goers at Lincoln Center.

name: Sarah Flint
description: Shoe designer. Inspired by origami and by classic shoe silhouettes of the 1940s, Flint's shoes are made in Italy and worn by Heidi Klum. She introduced her first collection in the fall of 2013 and has already been featured in The New York Times, Elle, Women's Wear Daily.

name: Alex Gartenfeld
description: Interim director, MOCA North Miami. Has served as online editor of Art in America and Interview magazines. Curated a summer show for OHWOW gallery in L.A. as well as an exhibition that took over Team Gallery's two locations in SoHo last winter. Recently named Interim Director of MOCA North Miami.

name: Wes Gordon
description: Fashion designer. A native of Atlanta, Gordon studied art and design in London and interned with Oscar de la Renta and Tom Ford. Michelle Obama, Gwyneth Paltrow, Kerry Washington and Emily Blunt wear his designs, which include gathered floor-length skirts and kimono jackets, accented with gold fabric, fur and hand-appliqued lace. He collaborates on shoes with Manolo Blahnik. Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman Marcus carry his clothes.

name: Nikolai "Niki" Haas, Simon Haas
description: Furniture designers, Haas Brothers. Raised in Austin, TX by a stone carver father, the twins came to furniture design by way of music. Simon studied art and architecture at RISD, before dropping out to join Nikolai and play in an L.A. band. Then they started making furniture, including couches covered in Icelandic reindeer fur with gold hoof-like feet. Peter Marino commissioned them to design a bar made of gold leaf bricks for a Louis Vuitton store in Shanghai. For Lady Gaga they created black polyethylene masks and for Versace a

name: Colin P. Kelly
description: Industrial designer, Redscout. Designed the elegantly simple $30 TOT booster seat for OXO that folds up for easy carrying and the TOT Sprout chair, that grows along with the child from 5 months to 6 years old. Also works on brand strategy and early-stage designs for everything from beauty products to cars. Other clients include PepsiCo, Target, Unilever. Won a slew of design awards including the IDSA gold.

name: Aimee Kestenberg
description: Handbag designer. Launched line of colorful leather handbags and backpacks in 2012. The company grossed $10 million in its first year. Revenues are set to double in 2013. Her bags are sold on her own site and at Nordstrom, Macy's, Shopbop.com, QVC and boutiques in more than a half dozen countries including Japan and Mexico. She's gotten a flood of press, from Real Simple to Vogue. Plans to expand into shoes, belts and clothes in 2014.

name: Jemima Kirke
description: Painter-actress. British-born Kirke has become famous playing the sexually adventurous party girl Jessa on the HBO series Girls. In real life she is an accomplished painter of expressionist portraits, who has had one-woman shows in Brooklyn and New York and group shows in London and Miami.

name: Becca McCharen
description: Fashion designer, Chromat. Fashion designer who makes sexy pieces using straps and braces, worn by Beyonce, Madonna, Nicki Minaj and Jessica Chastain. Featured in Elle, Vogue Italia, Details, WWD. McCharen founded the company in 2010. It is profitable and in the first half of 2013, her revenues of $280,000 had doubled 2012 sales. She expects sales of $800,000 in 2014.

name: Leandra Medine
description: Fashion blogger, The Man Repeller. Medine launched her blog in 2010 as a 21-year-old journalism student living with her parents on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Three years later, The Man Repeller bags millions of page views a month, and the concept of "man repelling"--or fashion the opposite sex doesn't get--has entered the fashion vernacular, as has "arm party," a term she coined to describe her habit of stacking her forearms with numerous bracelets. This year she published a book called "Man Repeller: Seeking Love. Finding Over
fraud: In 2020, Leandra Medine Cohen, founder of the influential fashion blog-turned-media brand Man Repeller, became central to a major scandal and controversy involving allegations of a toxic workplace and a lack of diversity, ultimately leading to her stepping down and the brand’s shutdown.

name: Shauna Miller
description: Fashion Blogger, Penny Chic. In 2010 Miller founded Penny Chic, a fashion blog featuring looks styled from clothes and accessories available at discount stores like Walmart, Forever 21 and JCPenney. She designed a 2013 collection for Walmart.com of made-in-America $20 little black dresses for every occasion; the first shipment sold out in one month. She has a deal with Little, Brown to publish a style book for teens and tweens.

name: Oscar Murillo
description: Artist. Before Murillo went to art school he was working odd hours as a cleaner in a London office building so he could have time to make art. Now his paintings fetch as much as $400,000 at auction and he shows with major gallery David Zwirner. His work spans performance, installation, painting, sculpture. His big canvases with graffiti-like scribbles and his big prices have prompted some to call him the next Basquiat.

name: Victo Ngai
description: Illustrator. Hong Kong-born Ngai does intricate, colorful editorial illustrations for a long list of clients including The New Yorker, The New York Times, Wired, McDonald's, Scientific American. She has won a slew of awards including two gold medals from the Society of Illustrators. One drawing for The New Yorker shows a full page of interlocking mayfly wings in vivid yellows, oranges and browns.

name: Lotta Nieminen
description: Graphic designer. Finnish-born Nieminen worked for fashion magazine Trendi, for Pentagram Design and RoAndCo Studio. Now an independent designer, her clients include The New York Times, Volkswagen, United Airlines, Newsweek. For fashion house Hermès, she designed brightly colored window display graphics that included images of a scuba diver, submarine and octopus. Her awards include the Art Directors Club Young Guns.

name: Aaron Poritz
description: Furniture designer. While visiting a friend in Nicaragua, Poritz stumbled on a supply of beautiful old growth wood uprooted by Hurricane Felix. Trained as an architect, he used the wood to create a line of furniture inspired by the minimalism and simplicity of Bauhaus designers like Marcel Breuer. His stools, chairs, tables, beds, sofas have no screws; they are fixed by unique joinery designed by Poritz.

name: Eric Singer
description: Eyewear designer, Shwood. While working in a movie theater, Singer made sunglasses using orange-colored Madrone branches and thrift store lenses. He met four guys who liked the glasses and became Singer's partners, selling through a makeshift website. The glasses caught on. Shwood launched in 2009 and now employs 50 people in Portland, OR. The glasses sell for as much as $350 online and in 300 stores worldwide including Nordstrom, Bloomingdales, Saks.

name: Travess Smalley
description: Digital artist. West Virginia-born Smalley blends computer graphics with physical collage-making. His colorful pieces look like a cross between a painting and a screen saver. One piece has Rothko-like stripes in blues, greens and yellows, with what appear to be cut-outs layered on top. He has had solo shows in New York, Toronto and Milan.

name: Lucien Smith
description: Artist. Smith makes canvases with layered oil paint and detritus like newspaper and aluminum pie plates. One painting shows a hazy seascape. Another piece: silk screens of indexes from biology textbooks, covered in plexiglass. He has also displayed found brooms meant to signify the sweeping gentrification in New York. Has shown in New York, L.A., Miami, Milan, London.

name: Danielle Snyder
description: Jewelry designer, Dannijo. Together with sister Jodie Snyder, 31, Florida native started making jewelry in middle school using her cardiologist father's medical tools. Has also run a non-profit that fundraises for grassroots projects in Africa. All the packaging for Dannijo is made by women in Rwanda. The jewelry line features bib necklaces of oxidized metals, stones like turquoise and carnelian, pieces of crystal, and vintage glass beads. Worn by Oprah, Beyonce, Madonna, Rihanna, Natalie Portman.

name: Tanya Taylor
description: Fashion designer. Canada native Taylor hand-paints the prints for the fabrics in her quirky ready-to-wear collections of skirts, tops, frocks, pantsuits and jackets. She also uses stripes, plaids, mauve leather and pink fur. Sold at Saks Fifth Avenue.

name: Torey Thornton
description: Artist. Macon, GA-born Thornton makes figurative, colorful, crude still lifes with acrylic, oil, glued collage and graphite. Other artists collect his work. He has had a one-man show in New York and group shows in New York and London. OHWOW gallery in Los Angeles recently started representing him and plans are in the works for a debut show.

name: Jacob Willis
description: Fashion designer, Second/Layer. Along with his brother Joshua and childhood friend, Anthony Franco, Jacob creates androgynous minimalist clothing designed and made in Los Angeles. They call their finely tailored day wear "Chicano Minimal." Created in conjunction with their branding firm, Second/Layer showed at the New York Public Library for New York Fashion Week Fall/Winter 2013. Their next showing will be in Paris.

name: Jamail Larkins
description: Founder, Ascension Air Management. He started flying at the age of 12 and was immediately hooked. While still a teen he sold instructional aviation manuals and equipment and also performed in air shows. In 2006 he formed a joint venture with an established broker to sell general aviation aircraft. His Ascension Air now sees $8 million in annual revenue and is a leading regional distributor for Cirrus Aircraft, the top manufacturer of piston-driven planes. But the most popular propeller-driven craft costs $850,000, and most pilots

name: Vince Alessi
description: Founder, Covaron Advanced Materials. Alessi invented a material that is easier to produce than advanced ceramics and uses less energy. Instead of traditional heat sintering, his “thermosetting” process resembles a two-part epoxy. Once ‘cured’ it has physical properties similar to a ceramic but is even stronger. Covaron, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., says it could replace steel, aluminum and certain plastics in various industries.

name: Miles Barr
description: Cofounder, Ubiquitous Energy. Miles Barr co-founded Ubiquitous Energy, which creates transparent coating that converts light into electricity. Barr's invention allows any surface to become an energy producer without impacting the way it looks. This means one day soon your smartphone could charge itself with just a little bit of light. Barr came up with this idea while working on a PhD in chemical engineering at MIT.

name: Eliza Becton
description: Cofounder, ReFresh Water. Eliza Becton's ReFresh Water is cutting out inefficiencies in the bottled water supply chain. Her company's vending kiosks are stocked with empty, collapsed bottles that are expanded and filled with a variety of flavored or sparkling waters at the time of sale. Her invention could reduce vending costs by 20% and the carbon footprint of bottled water by 80%.

name: John Bissell
description: Cofounder, Micromidas. Micromidas aims to turn trash into plastic. Founder Bissell invented a way to take waste material high in cellulose, like rice hulls, sawdust or cardboard and transform it into paraxylene, the primary feedstock for making polyester and plastic bottles. Chemical companies currently make paraxylene out of crude oil. Bissell has raised $25 million to build a pilot plant in Sacramento, Calif.

name: David Cohen-Tanugi
description: Ph.D. Candidate, Department of Materials, MIT. Cohen-Tanugi is working on filtration that will reduce the amount of salt in water, and thus the energy needed for desalination. Another project, Wristify, monitors air and skin temperature, and sends tailored pulses of hot or cold waveforms to the wrist to help maintain thermal comfort. The aim is to reduce the energy consumption of buildings by cooling and heating the individual –– not the building.

name: Jacob DeWitte
description: Founder, UPower. In far-off places with no access to electricity, gas-guzzling diesel generators are usually the primary means of getting electricity. UPower aims to end that wastefulness by developing a portable nuclear generator. A solid-state nuclear generator churning out 1.75 megawatts of power could, in theory, provide 12 years of energy without needing refueling and offer a 50% savings over diesel.

name: David Duel
description: Cofounder, ReGreen. By replacing inefficient systems, ReGreen has helped more than 3,000 buildings slash energy usage and reduce their water costs by an average 60%. Customers include CB Richard Ellis and Holiday Inn. They offer customers guaranteed payback on capital investments in two years and also provide innovative financing options. Founded in 2008, ReGreen now employs more than 100.

name: Jason Ethier
description: Cofounder, Dynamo Micropower. This 30-Under-30 returnee is developing a simplified, portable microturbine generator that can be used in remote areas or emergency situations. It can run on virtually any kind of fuel, even vodka. Ethier is also a founding director of clean tech incubator Greentown Labs in Boston, with more than 30 companies and 60 entrepreneurs.

name: Aaron Firestein
description: Cofounder, BucketFeet. Firestein, who speaks four languages, moved to Argentina after college to learn Spanish. He developed an eye for artist-designed shoes and connected with business partner, Raaja Nemani. They formed Bucketfeet, which creates $65 canvas sneakers featuring designs from street artists around the world. Sales totaled about $1 million in 2013.

name: Danielle Fong
description: Cofounder, LightSail Energy. How to solve renewable energy's intermittency problem? First, take wind or solar power and use it to compress air. Use the heat generated by compression to heat water. Store both until electricity is needed. Then, when you release the air, spray hot water into the airstream. The stream spins turbines to generate electricity. LightSail has received more than $30 million in funding.
fraud: Quoted to have been profitably selling energy tanks in 2014/2015 but also having reported shipping their first product in a tweet in March 2016

name: Eden Full
description: Founder, SunSaluter. Her low-cost solar panel tracks the sun across the sky using an ingeniously simple system of dripping water bottles. As water drips from bottles attached to one side, a counterweight swivels the panel, while a filtration system cleans the water. She's deployed early models to countries like Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania, helping 6,000 people get both clean water and power.

name: Bryce Goodman
description: Cofounder, BlueOak Resources. Electronic waste is the fastest growing waste stream in the world. Bryce Goodman's "urban mining" business, BlueOak Resources, gathers up tons of e-waste and "mines" it for valuable metals and minerals. Goodman is a former precious metals commodity trader and student at the Singularity University.

name: Ben Kaufman
description: Founder, Quirky. In high school, Kaufman tapped his parents’ home equity to create Mophie, an iPod accessory company he sold in 2007. In 2009 he launched Quirky, which develops consumer products through online collaboration with inventors. Quirky has raised $170 million, and sold a stake to GE to expand their co-branded WINK line of connected appliances. Estimated 2013 revenue is $50 million.

name: Adam Kell
description: Cofounder, FlameStower. Kell has invented a compact, portable power source for camping and wilderness adventures that generates electricity with heat from cookstoves or campfires. The heat energy is transformed into electric current that can charge USB-powered devices like cell phones. Kell's startup, FlameStower, is working to deploy the technology to needy families in sub-Saharan Africa.

name: Adam Khan
description: Founder, Akhan Tech. Diamonds are coming to the computer chip industry and Adam Khan's company, Akhan Technology, is at the forefront. Why diamonds? They conduct heat extremely well—whereas the traditional silicon wafers in computer chips break down after prolonged exposure to heat. Diamond chips could mean better circuitry for all sorts of electronic gear.

name: Eesha Khare
description: Young Scientist Award Winner, Intel International Science and Engineering Fair. Eesha’s invention could pave the way to a cell phone that can be fully charged in just seconds. Her supercapacitor energy-storage device utilizes a novel nanomaterial and nanostructure that she designed. She won the Young Scientist Award at the 2013 Intel International Science and Engineering Fair. A highlight of her success so far: getting interviewed by Conan O'Brien.

name: Andrew Krioukov
description: Cofounder, Building Robotics. Heating and cooling in buildings, which accounts for 21% of all US energy consumption, is fundamentally meant to make people comfortable, but is largely ignored. Using Andrew Krioukov's software, people become sensors for their buildings by requesting warmer / cooler temperatures and automatically indicating their presence. This data allows buildings to save substantial amounts of energy all while making people much more comfortable.

name: Daniel Maren, Andrew Ponec, Darren Hau
description: Cofounders, Dragonfly Systems. Dragonfly Systems is working to make solar panel systems cheaper, more efficient and reliable. "We’ve completely redesigned an often-overlooked component, the junction box, in a way that streamlines installation and improves reliability while boosting power output,” says Maren. They've gotten interest from the likes of SunPower and Altenergy, which are eager to try it out.

name: Jessica Matthews
description: Cofounder, Uncharted Play. Uncharted Play makes a soccer ball with a built-in battery. A half-hour of soccer absorbs enough kinetic energy to charge the battery and power a plugged-in LED light for five hours. This could help replace smoky kerosene lamps in towns without electricity. Next up: an electric-generating jump rope, skateboard and (American) football.

name: Sophie Ni
description: Cofounder, Takachar. Takachar aims to take organic waste discarded in some of the world's poorest cities, and transform it into valuable charcoal to be used in home cooking. This saves trees from being cut for charcoal, reduces waste streams, and saves carbon emissions.

name: Bill Pulte
description: CEO, Pulte Capital/Detroit Blight Authority. Pulte’s grandfather founded Pulte Group, America’s largest homebuilder. But his focus, as founder of the nonprofit Detroit Blight Authority, is on tearing down vacant homes and clearing away blight. He ditched a degree in journalism to run Pulte Capital Partners, a private equity firm that invests in building products companies. It has $30 million in revenues, and 200 employees.
fraud: Allegations suggest Pulte may have violated federal law by appointing himself chair of government-controlled mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

name: Lee Redden
description: Cofounder, Blue River Technology. As a Nebraska native, Lee Redden understood agriculture from an early age. Now, as cofounder of Blue River Technology, he's developed breakthrough technology that merges robotics, computer vision, and machine learning to deliver real-time, precise care for every plant, instead of the blanket approach all farmers are forced to use today.

name: Derek Rice
description: Cofounder, Rice Energy. In 2009 Derek started Rice Energy with his two 30-something brothers. By 2011, they had become one of the largest privately held oil and gas companies in Pennsylvania. By 2013 they were a top-40 producer of natural gas in the country. They have raised more than $600 million, much of it from Natural Gas Partners. An IPO could come soon.

name: Raphael Rosen
description: President, Carbon Lighthouse. Carbon Lighthouse studies energy-wasting buildings and designs systems that help owners dramatically reduce their energy use and thus their carbon footprint. So far they estimate that their 100-plus energy projects have prevented the emission of 26,000 tons of carbon dioxide.

name: Allison Lami Sawyer
description: Cofounder, Rebellion Photonics. Chemical plants and pipelines sometimes leak. Rebellion has developed a unique “hyperspectral” imaging technology that can see otherwise invisible gas leaks better than existing methods. This also holds big promise for defense and biological research applications. Company was spun out of Rice University.

name: Austin Stoffers, Jordan Schau, Michael Fishman, Zach Schau
description: Cofounders, Pure Fix Cycles. At school in Madison, Wisconsin four friends just wanted some basic bikes at a decent price. So they started making them. Soon their lightweight, no-frills, no-brakes, fixed-gear (or "fixie") bikes were in such demand they couldn't make enough. Pure Fix, now based in L.A., sells 25,000 bikes a year in dozens of colors. Sales surpassed $4 million in 2012.
fraud: Oakland County, Michigan, attorneys Austin Stoffers, Jordan Schau, and Michael Fishman were charged with fraud for a debt-collection scheme that victimized hundreds of debtors. The 2022 lawsuit alleges they filed fake proofs of service to obtain default judgments without proper notification. They faced criminal charges, potential prison time, and loss of law licenses.

name: Jesse Vollmar
description: Cofounder, FarmLogs. Vollmar grew up on his family's farm in Michigan and started an IT consulting business with classmate Brad Koch while in high school. In 2012, they launched FarmLogs. The software helps farmers manage risk while monitoring crops, expenses, profits, weather and prices. The web and mobile apps are used by commercial farms in 50 states and 121 countries.

name: Devin Walker
description: COO, Trash 2 Cash-Energy. Devin Walker is the COO of Trash 2 Cash-Energy (T2C-E), which has developed and patented a novel catalytic process to convert landfill gas to fuel. They provide one of the most sought after commodities while satisfying EPA landfill gas mitigation requirements.

name: Taylor Wilson
description: Nuclear prodigy, Thiel Fellow. At age 10 Wilson memorized the periodic table of elements. At 11 he built a bomb out of sugar and stump remover. At 14 he became the youngest ever to construct a working "fusor" or nuclear fusion reactor. After that he invented a cheap radiation detector. Now he's designing modular, fail-safe, small-scale nuclear fission reactors to be powered by nuclear waste.

name: Meg Gill
description: Cofounder, Golden Road Brewing. Beer, it's clear, isn't just for dudes. Women are drinking more of it. And as Meg Gill proves, they're making more of it, too. Amid America's craft beer explosion—more than 2,000 at last count—FORBES reckons that Gill, 28, is the youngest female brewery owner in the country. And her Los Angeles-based Golden Road Brewing is one of the fastest-growing; it produced 15,000 barrels last year and expects to double that output this year. "It's all about finding those relationships to help support the s

name: Elizabeth Alpern, Jeffrey Yoskowitz
description: Co-owners, The Gefilteria. Founders of the artisanal company for sustainably sourced, gourmet gefilte fish and other Old World Jewish foods. In addition to managing a food truck, Alpern spent several years working with food expert and cookbook author Joan Nathan. Yoskowitz, who is also the Gefilteria’s chief pickler, has written on food culture for the Atlantic, NY Times, Slate and Gastronomica.

name: Adam Altnether
description: Co-owner, Craft Restaurants. The St. Louis, Mo.-native quickly rose through the ranks of Craft Restaurant Group; he was Niche’s chef de cuisine by age 22, and then executive chef at Brasserie. Altnether spearheads the expansion of Pastaria, the group’s new Italian restaurant, and shares responsibilities as executive chef and owner of the entire dining empire with Gerard Craft.

name: Matt Brockman, Ross Brockman, Tyler Mosher
description: Founders, Downeast Cider House. Cider is having a moment, and these boys have made it their mission to build New England's first and largest craft hard cider company. When it comes to taste and quality, Downeast has a strict policy: no shortcuts. Sold in kegs and cans in parts of the east coast, the boys only use fresh pressed juices and pure, natural ingredients.

name: Borahm Cho
description: Cofounder, Kitchensurfing. Kitchensurfing is an online marketplace that matches up chefs and people who need a cook at a personalized budget. Users choose from a variety of engagements, from cooking lessons for kids to fried chicken parties to 10-course anniversary dinners. The site lets folks browse through photos and mini-profiles of chefs -- kind of like a dating website, but for foodies.

name: Emily Doubilet, Jessica Holsey
description: Cofounders, Susty Party. What better way to celebrate sustainability than through eco-friendly, compostable tableware? The colorful plates, bowls, cups and straws are all made in the U.S.A. from renewable harvested plants. Plates are made from tapioca starch mixed with grass fiber. The YouthTrade company partners with Clovernook Center to build employment opportunities for the blind.

name: Shore Gregory
description: Partner, Island Creek Oyster Bar. Located in Boston’s Kenmore Square, the bar originally started as an oyster farm. Now serves sustainable seafood, exceptional wines, and carefully selected craft beer. With an interior that is reminiscent of Duxbury Bay, Island Creek Oyster brings the farm to the restaurant by welcoming guests to connect with their oyster growers, harvesters, winemarkers, brewers and fishermen.

name: Eden Grinshpan
description: Host, "Eden Eats," Cooking Channel. As host of Cooking Channel's "Eden Eats," Grinshpan takes viewers into kitchens from around the world to explore how people have re-created their lives and culture through food. The Le Cordon Bleu graduate is also the current host of "Log On and Eat with Eden," where she travels around the U.S., visiting food bloggers, YouTube sensations and tweeters to find out their favorite dining spots.

name: Luke Holden
description: Founder, Luke's Lobster. A native of Cape Elizabeth, Me., Holden knows a thing or two about lobster rolls. Originally a fisherman turned investment banker after graduating from Georgetown University, he decided to follow his love for seafood and open up Luke's Lobster. Now, the company is rapidly expanding in the U.S., with 11 locations and a recently launched seafood company, Cape Seafood, which is Luke's main supplier of fresh seafood.

name: Yuki Ieto
description: Chef, Pubbelly Sushi. This sushi gastropub is the second restaurant to open in the widely-successful Pubbelly empire. Thanks to the menu's array of innovative rolls, craft beers and sake cocktails, Pubbelly Sushi hasn't had trouble packing the house every night. Since opening, Yuki and team have been recognized with accolades including Best Sushi 2013 from Miami New Times and Miami SunPost.

name: Jesse Katz
description: Head winemaker, Lancaster Estate and Roth Winery. Katz was the youngest hired head winemaker in the U.S. when he started at Lancaster Estate. In the past four years, he received 90+ scores on every Lancaster wine scored by Robert Parker. Celebs love him, too: Katz created a 2009 blend of Alexander Valley Cab “Blue Ocean Floor” for Jessica Biel and Justin Timberlake’s wedding. Previously at the Napa cult brand, Screaming Eagle.

name: Joseph "JJ" Johnson
description: Chef de cuisine, The Cecil. Chef de cuisine at Richard Parson's new Afro-Asian-American brasserie in Harlem, N.Y. Under guidance of executive chef Alexander Smalls, JJ has crafted a menu integrating culinary traditions of African Diaspora. Spent time in Ghana studying West African cuisine before honing his talents in the kitchens of the city's most highly esteemed: Centro Vinoteca, Jane, Tribeca Grill.

name: Vincent Kitirattragarn
description: Founder, Dang Foods. The engineer turned entrepreneur started Dang Foods in 2011 after his mother gave him a recipe for Miang Kum, a Northern Thai dish that called for toasted coconut. The gluten-free snacks are made from sliced coconut meat, simply seasoned with salt and sugar for a buttery umani flavor. Nibblers can find them in Safeway and Whole Foods stores.

name: Oliver Kremer
description: Cofounder, Dos Toros Taqueria. West of the Mississippi, Kremer's burrito spot of choice is Gordo Taqueria. But when he discovered that there were no authentic S.F. Mission-styled taquerias in N.Y., he decided to open one himself. The Berkeley, Cali.-native opened his first Dos Toros shop in 2009. Now in four locations with plans to expand in D.C. and Philly in late 2014.

name: Adam Lowy
description: Founder, Move for Hunger. Founded in 2009, Move For Hunger is the first and only non-profit that works with the relocation industry to support local food banks. The organization mobilizes moving companies to collect unopened, non-perishable items during the move and delivers them to the banks. To date, it has moved over 2.4 million pounds of food in the U.S. -- enough to feed 2 million.

name: Aditi Malhotra
description: Founder, Tache Artisan Chocolate. The CEO-chocolatier trained in Switzerland at Glion Institute and then spent several months training with Christian Vautier before opening her own artisan chocolaterie. The boutique also specializes in chocolate-making classes for kids and adults. Among the addictive varieties to choose from: Moroccan five spice and date truffles with peri peri (an African chili), bonbons and mustache-shape chocolate lollipops.

name: Carlton McCoy
description: Wine Director, The Little Nell Hotel. The Culinary Arts Program (C-CAP) alum recently debuted a new wine tasting program in The Little Nell’s cellar, allowing hotel guests a casual apres ski tasting with a sommelier. McCoy is the second African American and one of 133 top wine professionals to have earned the title of Master Sommelier in the U.S. Formerly of Per Se, Aquavit, Craft Steak.

name: Jack McGarry
description: Co-owner, The Dead Rabbit. As head bartender of the Victorian-era saloon, McGarry leads the extensive cocktail menu, which holds 72 libations and is the largest selection of Irish whiskey in New York. Recently the youngest to be crowned "International Bartender of the Year" at the Tales of the Cocktail's Spirited Awards, a ceremony referred to as the "Oscars" of the spirits community.

name: Leslie Pariseau
description: Deputy editor, PUNCH. Cofounded a new online booze publication with editor-in-chief, Talia Baiocchi, who made the list in this category last year. PUNCH, published in collaboration with Ten Speed Press, uses narrative journalism to explore the culture of wine, cocktails and spirits. Previously, Pariseau worked for Momofuku Ssam Bar and reported for the U.N., GQ, Esquire and Saveur.

name: Thomas Pastuszak
description: Wine director, The NoMad Restaurant. Pastuszak's head was in the right place when he decided to make a career switch from medicine to wine. The New Yorker has taken on roles at Stella's and Colicchio & Sons. When the team behind Eleven Madison Park opened The NoMad, Pastuszak was asked to lead the wine program, helping it achieve its 3-Star N.Y. Times rating.

name: Alex Pemoulie
description: Founder, Thirty Acres. Pemoulie opened Thirty Acres with her husband in 2012. Menu boasts American food with seasonal dishes, focusing on local products. Dishes like tortelloni with hazelnut, ricotta, butternut squash, and cremini mushrooms reflect the cultural melting pot of N.J. Pemoulie is also director of finance at Momofuku, where she oversees projections, budgets and costs of all 10 of the group’s restaurants.

name: Jason Pfeifer
description: Chef de cuisine, Maialino. After graduating from the Culinary Institute of America and working stints at Per Se and Gramercy Tavern, Pfeifer took a Denmark voyage to apprentice with the world-renowned chef Rene Redzepi at Noma. Now at Maialino, the Roman-style trattoria named after "Little Pig," he continues to coax the menu with roast suckling pork and other central-Italian delicacies.

name: Eric Railsback
description: Cofounder, Les Marchands Wine Bar & Merchant, Lieu Dit Winery. Formerly ran wine programs of Osteria Mozza and Gordon Ramsey in Los Angeles. Now operates Les Marchands, a French-inspired wine bar and retail shop in Santa Barbara, Cali. With import selections that are both relevant and Eurocentric, Railsback strives to create an environment where wine is less pretentious and more accessible for younger people who are interested in the culture.

name: Ali Rosen
description: Founder, Potluck Video. Founded the online video website covering food and drinks, from sit-downs with Grant Achatz and Mario Batali to reels on the road showcasing local drinks in Ecuador. Rosen’s gateway into food started at The Daily Meal, where she started and produced the site’s video network. Watch for her show on NYCTV in February this year.

name: Erica Shea, Stephen Valand
description: Cofounders, Brooklyn Brew Shop. The idea is simple: if you can make oatmeal, you can make beer. Shea and Valand quit their jobs in 2009 to start their business of easy-to-use beer-brewing kits. Designed for stove-tops, the kit takes up less than one-square-foot of space and even looks stylish in the average pint-sized N.Y. apartment. Sold in over 2,500 retailers in Canada, Norway, Switzerland, Singapore.

name: Rob Spiro
description: Cofounder, Good Eggs. At Good Eggs, foods are made by local farmers and artisan producers, encouraging a more intimate connection between the consumer and the farmer. The online marketplace delivers everything from green produce to serious preparations, like Texas style brisket, for instance, that would be delicious with fresh-baked baguettes or “Grandma rolls.” Launches in Brooklyn, New Orleans, Los Angeles are in the works.

name: Ben Towill, Philip Winser
description: Cofounders, Silkstone Group. Founded Silkstone Group, one of N.Y.'s leading creative events agencies. Since 2010, the two have opened three successful restaurants: The Fat Radish, The East Pole and The Leadbelly. Towill, a passionate advocate of using local and seasonal organic produce, oversees the menu, while Phil leads the design team on Silkstone projects.

name: Christina Turley
description: Director of sales and marketing, Turley Wine Cellars. A true graduate of the David Chang University, Turley started as sommelier at Momofuku Ko before landing beverage director for all four restaurants (Noodle Bar, Ssam Bar, Ko & Ma Peche) in the group. Now leads the sales team at her family-owned winery. Her most prized project, the White Zinfandel, sold out its 200 cases in two hours.

name: Jason Wang
description: CEO, Xi'an Famous Foods. What once began as a 200-square-foot stall in 2005 has now expanded to seven locations in N.Y. The chain, named for the capital of China’s Shaanxi province, is first to bring the little-known cuisine to the U.S. Wang works with his father to serve locals with authentic family recipes, from hand-ripped "biang biang" noodles seared in hot oil to fire-hued lamb burgers.

name: Catherine Zamoiski
description: Director of marketing, Pret A Manger. Oversees the national marketing team at Pret, which now has 56 locations in four U.S. cities and 250 locations in London. Previously managed marketing teams at Branded Restaurants and Wichcraft, and was an editor at Restaurant Girl, an early blog about restaurants. Received M.A. in Food Management from NYU.

name: Michelle Phan
description: Founder of ipsy, YouTube beauty influencer with subscription cosmetics company expected to yield $120M in revenues
fraud: Lawsuit: Sued by Ultra Records (Jul 2014) for copyright infringement over music in YouTube videos. Settled Aug 2015. Also victim of $4M theft by attorney Michael Avenatti (convicted 2022).

name: Catharine Ahearn
description: Sculptor studying MFA at UCLA, solo shows in New York and group shows in Toronto, Brussels, London, Shanghai

name: Alison Chemla
description: Jewelry designer at Alison Lou, makes 14-karat gold pieces worn by Beyonce, Rihanna, Emma Roberts

name: Sara Cwynar
description: Photographer who reprints and scans found images, solo shows in New York, Philadelphia, Amsterdam, Toronto

name: Lindsay Degen
description: Knitwear designer, won 2014 Ecco Domani Fashion Foundation award, designed for Victoria's Secret

name: Danielle DiFerdinando
description: Handbag designer at Danielle Nicole, bags in 500 Macy's stores, $11.5M in sales in 2014

name: Phoebe English
description: Fashion designer called British fashion star in the making by Vogue, Lorde wears her clothes

name: Charlie Engman
description: Fashion and fine art photographer, commercial clients include Hermes and LaCoste

name: Tatyana Fazlalizadeh
description: Artist doing street and gallery art addressing themes from sexual harassment to Arab Spring

name: Chiara Ferragni
description: Fashion blogger at The Blonde Salad, $8M revenues, shoes in 200 stores in 25 countries
fraud: Italian influencer Chiara Ferragni was involved in a major 2023–2025 scandal dubbed "Pandorogate" regarding misleading, charity-linked sales of a "Pink Christmas" pandoro cake, which led to a €1 million fine, criminal investigation for aggravated fraud, and lawsuits, but she was cleared of fraud charges in January 2026

name: Gaia
description: Street artist with murals in museums in Istanbul, Spoleto, Baltimore Museum of Art

name: Nate Mell
description: Ceramicist and cofounder of Felt+Fat producing porcelain tableware

name: Kerby Jean-Raymond
description: Fashion designer at Pyer Moss, designs wardrobe for Usher's live shows

name: Jamian Juliano-Villani
description: Painter making colorful cartoon-like work, shown in Tokyo, South Korea, Miami Beach
fraud: New York artist Jamian Juliano-Villani is being accused by another artist of having sticky fingers. Brooklyn’s Scott Teplin sees too much similarity between a small painting by Juliano-Villani, now on view at West Village gallery Gavin Brown’s Enterprise, and a painting of his own.

name: Janessa Leone
description: Hat designer, $1.1M in 2014, hats worn by Blake Lively, Lupita Nyong'o, Kate Hudson

name: Misha Nonoo
description: Fashion designer making feminine ready-to-wear, clothes at Bergdorf Goodman, $4M sales in 2013

name: Darlene Okpo
description: Fashion designer at William Okpo, named after Nigerian immigrant father

name: Lizzy Okpo
description: Fashion designer at William Okpo with sister Darlene, fan base includes Solange Knowles

name: Matthew Orley
description: Fashion designer at Orley with brother Alex and wife Samantha, CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund finalist

name: Alex Orley
description: Fashion designer at Orley producing classic menswear with youthful touch

name: Samantha Orley
description: Fashion designer at Orley, launching women's wear collection in 2015

name: Kour Pour
description: Artist making large scale paintings of Oriental carpets, first NY solo show sold out

name: Tabor Robak
description: Video and digital artist creating 3-D video game-inspired imagery, shown at MOMA PS 1

name: Simone Rocha
description: Fashion designer, Harper's Bazaar Young Designer of the Year 2014

name: Borna Sammak
description: Artist making video collages and heat transfers, shown in New York, Shanghai

name: Jacolby Satterwhite
description: Artist making 3-D videos, work in Whitney, Studio Museum in Harlem, Seattle Art Museum

name: Christian Siriano
description: Fashion designer, youngest Project Runway winner, $6.5M+ revenues from clothing line
fraud: Red carpet darling and New York Fashion Week mainstay Christian Siriano has a reputation to uphold for “creating high- end dresses,” which is precisely why the brand decided to pull out of a licensing deal late last year. According to a $10 million-plus lawsuit filed against Christian Siriano Holdings in November by wholesaler M&A Imports, the Project Runway alumni illegally walked back on the parties’ licensing deal, which gave M&A the right to slap the Siriano brand name all over its collection of “ladies’ dresses, girls’ dresses, intimates, and sleepwear.”

name: LaQuan Smith
description: Fashion designer who dressed Beyonce, Lady Gaga, Kim Kardashian, $500K revenue

name: Amanda Thomas
description: Jewelry designer at Luv Aj, celebrity clients include Kim Kardashian, Miley Cyrus

name: Stewart Uoo
description: Artist making provocative sculptures and photographs, shown at Whitney Museum

name: Vhils
description: Portuguese street artist with murals in 50+ cities, directed music video for U2

name: Marissa Vosper
description: Lingerie designer at Negative Underwear, sold out first collection in 2.5 weeks

name: Jessica Walsh
description: Graphic designer at Sagmeister & Walsh, work exhibited at Louvre, LA MOCA

name: Palmer Luckey
description: Founder of Oculus VR, sold to Facebook for $2 billion
fraud: Palmer Luckey, founder of Oculus VR, was involved in a major 2017 lawsuit where a jury awarded ZeniMax Media $500 million for broken NDAs and copyright infringement regarding Oculus technology

name: Alex Banayan
description: Venture associate at Alsop Louie Partners

name: Brett Berson
description: Vice President at First Round Capital

name: Cameron Teitelman
description: Founder of StartX accelerator

name: CeCe Cheng
description: Director of Dorm Room Fund at First Round Capital

name: Topher Conway
description: Partner at SV Angel

name: Rafael Corrales
description: Partner at Charles River Ventures

name: Adam D'Augelli
description: Principal at True Ventures

name: Brandon Farwell
description: Partner at Rothenberg Ventures

name: Bryan Gartner
description: VP at Insight Venture Partners

name: Matt Huang
description: Partner at Sequoia Capital

name: Gaurav Jain
description: Principal at Founder Collective

name: Annie Kadavy
description: Partner at Charles River Ventures

name: Rebecca Kaden
description: Partner at Maveron

name: Holly Maloney
description: Principal at North Bridge

name: Katerina Markov
description: Venture Partner at AF Square

name: Arun Mathew
description: Principal at Accel Partners

name: Max Motschwiller
description: Senior associate at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers

name: Chris Paik
description: General partner at Thrive Capital

name: Will Peng
description: Managing partner at Red Swan Ventures

name: Chetan Puttagunta
description: Partner at New Enterprise Associates

name: Victoria Song
description: Principal at Flybridge Capital Partners

name: Nikhil Basu Trivedi
description: Senior associate at Shasta Ventures

name: Stephanie Weiner
description: Analyst at Bain Capital Ventures

name: Shivon Zilis
description: Founding member of Bloomberg Beta
fraud: Shivon Zilis, a top AI executive and Neuralink director, has been involved in several high-profile, interconnected controversies and legal scenarios, primarily stemming from her professional and personal relationship with Elon Musk, as well as her role in the evolving OpenAI, Microsoft, and xAI corporate drama.

name: Evan Spiegel
description: Cofounder and CEO of Snapchat
fraud: Lawsuits: Paid $157.5M (2014) to settle ousted co-founder Reggie Brown's lawsuit. Child safety lawsuits - New Mexico AG (2024). Parents suing over teens' fentanyl deaths (2025). Social media addiction trial - settled Jan 2026. Sexism charges at Snap (2018). Leaked filthy college emails scandal (2014).

name: Jacob Bank
description: Cofounder of Timeful (acquired by Google)

name: James Beshara
description: Cofounder of Tilt crowdfunding platform

name: George Bousis
description: Founder of Raise gift card marketplace

name: John Brooks
description: Founder of Ricochet

name: Umang Dua
description: Cofounder of Handy home services
fraud: The lawsuits aimed to compel the company to compensate workers for unpaid time and expenses, arguing that despite being labeled "contractors," they were overseen and managed like employees.

name: Steve Fernholz
description: Founder of Droplet

name: Dylan Field
description: Cofounder of Figma design tool
fraud: In April 2025, it was reported that Figma sent a cease-and-desist letter to a competitor, Lovable, regarding the use of the term "Dev Mode".

name: Jared Hecht
description: Cofounder of Fundera small business loans

name: Rand Hindi
description: Founder of Snips AI assistant

name: Ryan Hoover
description: Founder of Product Hunt

name: Mike Krieger
description: Cofounder of Instagram

name: Elan Miller
description: Cofounder of Glimpse

name: Jonas Piela
description: Cofounder of Avuba

name: James Proud
description: Founder of Hello (Sense sleep tracker)
fraud: A lawsuit accused Proud of a campaign of stalking and harassment. Further reports indicated an alleged cover-up of these behaviors within a startup environment

name: Jon Reynolds
description: Cofounder of SwiftKey keyboard

name: Sam Rosen
description: Founder of MakeSpace storage

name: Ryan Shea
description: Cofounder of Onename blockchain identity

name: Lauren Talbot
description: Founder of Pvll

name: Willem Van Lancker
description: Cofounder of Oyster e-books

name: Yifan Zhang
description: Cofounder of Pact fitness app

name: Afrojack
description: DJ and producer
fraud: DJ Afrojack (Nick van de Wall) faced a $25 million lawsuit in 2017 from ex-girlfriend Lauren Meditz, alleging controlling behavior, fraud, and emotional distress. Separately, in 2025, he was mentioned in court regarding a tax fraud case involving his former advisor, though he was not charged. He was also named in a 2012 lawsuit by Lindsay Lohan regarding song lyrics.

name: Arca
description: Music producer worked with Bjork, Kanye West, FKA Twigs

name: Iggy Azalea
description: Rapper with hit Fancy

name: Azealia Banks
description: Rapper and singer
fraud: Controversies: Subpoenaed in Elon Musk lawsuit (2019). Dropped from UK festival (2016) for racist/homophobic tweets at Zayn Malik. Twitter suspended repeatedly. Claimed assault by Russell Crowe (2016) - DA declined charges. Threatening to sue Matty Healy (2024). Multiple public feuds with celebrities. Released Conor McGregor nudes (Jul 2025).

name: Big Sean
description: Rapper signed to Kanye West's GOOD Music

name: Chance the Rapper
description: Independent rapper from Chicago
fraud: Lawsuits: Sued by former manager Pat Corcoran (2020) for $3M+ alleging unpaid wages, breach of contract, fraud. Trial pending. Copyright infringement lawsuit (2017) for unauthorized sample on 10 Day mixtape. Child support legal dispute.

name: FKA Twigs
description: Singer and dancer known for avant-garde style

name: Martin Garrix
description: DJ and producer of Animals

name: Will Griggs
description: Cofounder of Cantora music tech

name: Hit-Boy
description: Producer for Jay-Z, Kanye West, Beyonce

name: Hozier
description: Singer-songwriter of Take Me to Church

name: Mike Will Made It
description: Producer for Miley Cyrus, Rihanna, Future
fraud: Jamaican artist Flourgon (Michael May) alleges that Miley Cyrus's 2013 hit "We Can't Stop," which Mike Will Made It produced, infringes upon his 1988 Jamaican chart-topping song, "We Run Things".

name: Kacey Musgraves
description: Country singer, Grammy winner

name: DJ Mustard
