name: Lakeith Stanfield
title: Actor
fraud:
LaKeith Stanfield, who was recognized on Forbes' 30 Under 30 list in 2017, has been involved in several controversies and lawsuits.

In February 2024, Stanfield and his wife were sued by their former nanny, Monica Sawyer, for alleged labor code violations and unpaid wages. Sawyer claimed that during an 8-day trip in October 2023, she was overworked with constant demands and received no time to eat, sleep, or shower, and was not paid the agreed-upon $500 per day.

Additionally, in December 2023, Stanfield faced accusations of stealthing and sexual assault, with some of his friends reportedly alluding to these allegations in a group chat. He also faced controversy in May 2021 for his participation as a moderator in a Clubhouse room where antisemitic remarks were made. Stanfield stated that he did not say anything antisemitic himself and vehemently rejects all forms of hate speech.

name: Melissa Villaseñor
title: Comedian
fraud: Melissa Villaseñor, a comedian and impressionist who was a cast member on "Saturday Night Live" from 2016 to 2022, faced controversy in 2016 regarding old tweets. Some of these tweets, which were deleted, contained offensive language and racial insensitivity. Villaseñor addressed the situation at the time, acknowledging that she had posted "dumb things on social media for a long time." She has not been publicly associated with any lawsuits, scandals, or other controversies beyond this past tweet issue.

name: Evan Rachel Wood
title: Actor
fraud: Evan Rachel Wood, who was named to the Forbes 30 Under 30 list in 2016, has publicly accused musician Marilyn Manson (Brian Warner) of abuse. Wood detailed her experiences of alleged grooming, psychological, physical, and sexual abuse, and manipulation, which she states began when she was a teenager and continued for years. In February 2021, Wood named Manson as her alleged abuser on Instagram, and several other women have come forward with similar allegations against him. While the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department investigated Manson, the district attorney's office stated that more evidence was needed to file charges. Wood had previously testified about her experiences with domestic violence and sexual abuse to a House Judiciary subcommittee in 2018, advocating for a bill of rights for sexual assault survivors.

name: Karlie Kloss
title: Supermodel
fraud: In 2017, Karlie Kloss faced controversy for her photoshoot in Vogue where she was styled as a geisha. Critics accused the spread of cultural appropriation, leading Kloss to issue an apology on Twitter. This was not the only instance where Kloss was criticized for cultural insensitivity; in 2012, she wore a Native American-inspired headdress during the Victoria's Secret fashion show, which also resulted in an apology. Additionally, a book titled "Kushner, Inc." alleged that Kloss was not approved by her husband's family and may have been banned from gatherings for six years.

name: Sandy Liang
title: Fashion Designer
fraud: Sandy Liang has faced accusations of plagiarism from Forever 21. In 2017, Liang called out the fast-fashion retailer for selling jackets that were nearly identical to her designs from her Fall/Winter 2015 and Fall/Winter 2016 collections. She posted on Instagram about the similarities, stating that Forever 21 was "rip[ping] off young designers" and that it was "incredibly gross" to profit from another designer's ideas. Forever 21 has a history of being accused of plagiarism by other designers.

name: re
title: Fashion designer
fraud: The founder of Frank, Charlie Javice, who was featured on Forbes' "30 Under 30" list in 2019, was convicted of defrauding JPMorgan Chase. Prosecutors accused her of artificially inflating her startup's customer list by ten times, leading to JPMorgan acquiring Frank for $175 million. Javice was found guilty of four fraud counts and one conspiracy charge, and was sentenced to 85 months in prison. JPMorgan also sued Javice separately, seeking to recover the funds paid for her startup. The case has been compared to that of Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes.

name: Ashley Nell Tipton
title: Fashion designer
fraud: The winner of Project Runway Season 14, Ashley Nell Tipton, faced controversy surrounding her win and her collection. Tim Gunn, a judge on the show, publicly criticized her winning collection as "hideous" and suggested her victory "reeked of tokenism". Reports also indicate that Marriott terminated its partnership with Sonder due to a default, leading to the abrupt closure of Sonder's operations and leaving guests with little notice to vacate. Accusations have also surfaced regarding Sonder's leadership potentially threatening to lock out guests as leverage for emergency funds. Francis Davidson himself announced his departure from the company in June 2025, stating that "What unfolded over the following years was far worse than anything we'd seen in historical data or ever imagined was possible".

Charlie Kirk, who was recognized by Forbes in their 2018 "30 Under 30" list for Law & Policy, has been associated with several controversies and legal issues involving his organization, Turning Point USA (TPUSA).

Turning Point Action, an affiliate of TPUSA, was fined $18,000 by the Federal Election Commission (FEC) for failing to disclose donors. This fine stemmed from a complaint filed by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW), alleging that TPUSA Action failed to report over $33,000 in contributions intended to influence the 2020 election.

Additionally, a former TPUSA employee alleged that the organization shared personal information of over 700 student supporters with an employee of Marco Rubio's presidential campaign. There have also been concerns raised by tax experts regarding whether TPUSA's conduct during a pro-Donald Trump event in 2016 may have violated its tax-exempt status, though TPUSA disputed these claims.

Furthermore, TPUSA has been criticized for its role in promoting misinformation, including claims about the 2020 election results, COVID-19 vaccines, and other topics. The organization has also faced scrutiny for its fundraising practices, including the use of "dark money" operations to keep donors' identities secret.

More recently, there have been attempts to trademark the name "Turning Point USA" and "Charlie Kirk" by individuals seeking to profit from Kirk's legacy, especially after his death. There has also been controversy surrounding an AI-generated song, "We Are Charlie Kirk," which was criticized for its potentially extremist propaganda.

fraud: Yes, David Ouaknine and his company, CDI Furniture, were involved in a lawsuit with Halo Creative & Design Limited. Halo sued CDI Furniture and Ouaknine for intellectual property infringement, including copyright, patent, and trademark rights. A jury found in favor of Halo, determining that CDI willfully infringed on two design patents, the ODEON trademark, and nine copyrights. The jury awarded Halo damages totaling over $1.5 million for patent and trademark infringement, and an additional $2.5 million for copyright infringement. An email exchange from 2013 indicated that Ouaknine was warned about Halo's copyrights by a supplier, yet CDI continued to sell the infringing Mars Chair. The case involved legal arguments about forum non conveniens, with the Federal Circuit eventually reversing a lower court's dismissal and remanding the case for further proceedings.

fraud:
Charlie Javice, who was recognized on Forbes' "30 Under 30" list in 2019 for her student financial planning startup Frank, has been at the center of a significant lawsuit and fraud scandal. She was convicted of fraud and conspiracy charges and sentenced to seven years and one month in prison in September 2025, though she remains out on bail while appealing her conviction. fraud: Andrew Kaczynski, a recipient of the Forbes 30 Under 30 award in the media category in 2018, has been involved in a controversy regarding CNN's reporting methods. While Kaczynski's reporting identified the user, CNN initially stated they would not reveal the identity because the user was a private citizen who had apologized. However, CNN added a disclaimer that they reserved the right to publish the identity if circumstances changed, which led to accusations of blackmail. This research has drawn attention to the ethical implications of AI and has led to advocacy for greater accountability in the tech industry.
*   **DumpID.me Petition:** In 2022, the Algorithmic Justice League, co-founded by Buolamwini, collaborated on a petition called DumpID.me. This petition called for the IRS to stop using ID.me, a facial recognition technology, for user logins. The IRS eventually agreed to halt the program.

This penalty stemmed from a television viewer who emailed the LPGA to report a rule violation Thompson committed the previous day. LPGA officials investigated the claim and determined that Thompson had breached Rule 20-7c (Playing From Wrong Place), resulting in a two-stroke penalty. She also received an additional two-stroke penalty for returning an incorrect scorecard, as she was unaware of the breach when she signed it. Thompson ultimately lost the major in a playoff to So Yeon Ryu. This incident generated significant controversy and criticism from fellow golfers and the public, with many questioning the fairness of penalties issued after the fact based on viewer input.

In another incident in 2020 at the Women's British Open, Thompson was involved in a situation where she moved grass away from her ball with her club head before a shot. While some fans and observers viewed this as a potential rule violation that could improve her lie, it was ultimately determined by officials that the grass had returned to its original position, and therefore, no breach of Rule 8.1 occurred. Although she did not make the cut in that tournament, she avoided a penalty.

More recently, in 2023, Thompson faced scrutiny after a Solheim Cup match where she shanked a crucial shot on the 18th hole. In the post-round press conference, she initially refused to comment on the shot, a response that was labeled a "terrible question" by U.S. captain Stacy Lewis. Krish Ramineni and Sam Udotong, co-founders of Fireflies.ai, have been involved in discussions and a lawsuit related to their company's practices.

In late 2025, news broke that Fireflies.ai's early product development involved the founders manually taking notes during meetings while presenting the service as an AI bot. This practice, which occurred in 2017 during beta testing, led to a debate about "fake it till you make it" startup strategies. While the founders stated they were transparent with beta customers about having a "human in the loop", some users criticized this approach as misrepresentation and potential fraud.

More significantly, Fireflies.ai is facing a class-action lawsuit filed in Illinois federal court, *Cruz v. Fireflies.AI Corp.*. The lawsuit alleges that the company illegally collects and stores biometric voice data of meeting participants without their knowledge or consent, violating Illinois' Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA). The complaint asserts that Fireflies.ai's tool records, analyzes, transcribes, and stores unique vocal characteristics ("voiceprints") of all participants, including those who are not users of the service. The plaintiffs argue that these voiceprints are sensitive biometric identifiers and that the company lacks a public retention and destruction policy for this data.

fraud: A class-action lawsuit was filed against Kalshi, alleging that the company duped customers by advertising a peer-to-peer service while operating an in-house market maker, Kalshi Trading. The lawsuit claims that Kalshi users bet not only against each other but also against the house, with Kalshi's institutional market makers gambling against the consumer. Luana Lopes Lara, a co-founder of Kalshi, responded to the lawsuit by stating that it mischaracterized Kalshi Trading's role and that such a setup is common and regulated in the industry, providing liquidity and a better user experience. She also referred to the lawsuit as a "smear campaign" backed by a competitor and described the allegations as baseless. Kalshi Trading, according to Lopes Lara, receives no preferential treatment and operates as a separate team. Another lawsuit from last year also made similar allegations about Kalshi's dedicated trading team functioning like a sportsbook.

name: Alexis Nikole Nelson
title: Cofounder
fraud:
Alexis Nikole Nelson, also known as "Black Forager," has faced controversy, primarily stemming from racist comments in online discussions. Some individuals have expressed anger or discomfort with her using the term "Black" in her online persona, associating it with an unnecessary injection of race and politics into foraging. These reactions have been met with explanations that highlight the historical context of foraging practices and how laws were implemented to disenfranchise Black people and other minorities. Discussions have also touched upon "botanical racism" and the intersection of environmentalism and race, which Nelson brings to light in her work.

There is no indication in the provided search results of any lawsuits filed against Alexis Nikole Nelson.

name: Haibin Yang & David Zhao
title: Cofounders
fraud: Yes, Haibin Yang and David Zhao, associated with Chubby Cattle International, have been involved in several controversies. Their restaurants, including Chubby Cattle and Niku X, have faced closures due to health code violations and accusations of Salmonella outbreaks. There are also allegations of misleading advertising regarding the sourcing of their Wagyu beef, with claims of a non-existent ranch and cattle herd. David Zhao has publicly responded to some of these allegations.

name: Jake Cohen
title: Author
fraud: Jake Cohen, a prominent Jewish food personality, was named in a federal discrimination lawsuit filed by former Feedfeed employees. The lawsuit alleged racism and sexism at the food media company where Cohen worked as editorial and test kitchen director from 2018 to 2020. The former employees, both women of color, accused Cohen of mistreatment, verbal abuse, and creating a hostile work environment, claiming he treated them like maids, shouted at them, and made offensive comments. The lawsuit also alleged that Cohen discouraged one of the employees from having children and made a comment about "crazy rich Asians" living in his building at the beginning of the pandemic. Cohen, who left Feedfeed in August 2020, denied the allegations, stating they were false, misleading, and/or embellished. The lawsuit was settled out of court.

name: Alanah Pearce
title: Writer
fraud:
Alanah Pearce, a recipient of Forbes' 30 Under 30 recognition for her work in games, has been associated with controversies, primarily concerning allegations of misrepresenting her role in the development of "God of War: Ragnarök" and an incident involving alleged art theft.

Critics have claimed that Pearce overstated her contributions to "God of War: Ragnarök," suggesting she was a writer when her credited role was as an accessibility consultant. Additionally, in 2019, she faced accusations of stealing artwork and attempting to pass it off as her own, an accusation she later acknowledged and apologized for.

It is important to note that separate from Pearce's own controversies, the "Forbes 30 Under 30" list has, in some instances, included individuals who later faced legal troubles and scandals, such as Charlie Javice, founder of Frank, who was charged with fraud related to the sale of her company to JP Morgan.

name: Ian Proulx & Nicholas Bagamian
title: Cofounders
fraud:
Ian Proulx, co-founder of 1047 Games, faced controversy after wearing a "Make FPS Great Again" hat at the Summer Game Fest in 2025. This was seen by many as a politically charged meme, drawing criticism from gamers and fellow developers. Proulx initially defended his choice, stating it was not a political statement, but later apologized, admitting it was a marketing stunt gone wrong and that he was sorry for causing division within the community.

Additionally, in July 2025, 1047 Games announced layoffs and the shutting down of the original Splitgate game, with CEO Ian Proulx and CTO Nicholas Bagamian acknowledging that the game was launched "too early" and that the company had made "many, many mistakes."

name: Jacob Wolf
title: Chief Reporter
fraud: Jacob Wolf, a Forbes 30 Under 30 winner and chief reporter for Dot Esports, was the subject of a lawsuit filed by SoftGivng (now known as Brandfluence). Softgiving alleged that Wolf conspired with four other defendants to defame the company and demanded that he not publish an investigation he had conducted into their practices. Wolf denied these allegations and stated his intention to fight the lawsuit in court. The investigation reportedly revealed that Softgiving collected a significant portion of charity donations.

name: Rachell Hofstetter
title: Content Creator
fraud: Rachell Hofstetter, also known as Valkyrae, faced controversy regarding her skincare brand, RFLCT. Launched in October 2021, RFLCT claimed to protect gamers' skin from blue light emitted by screens. However, the brand received backlash due to a lack of sufficient scientific evidence supporting its claims. Experts stated that prolonged screen time was unlikely to cause skin damage unless someone already had pre-existing conditions like melasma or hyperpigmentation. Hofstetter acknowledged the criticism, stating that the concerns were valid and that she was upset by the lack of information on the brand's website. She also expressed that she was contractually bound to RFLCT and wished to part ways with the brand. The controversy significantly impacted her mental health, but she later stated that she was recovering and did not want the situation to hinder her further. Additionally, Hofstetter's cameo was cut from "A Minecraft Movie" after she made comments about Jason Momoa mistreating crew members, which she stated she would "much rather not have that 30 seconds than be sued."

name: Madison Campbell and Liesel Vaidya
title: Cofounders
fraud:
Yes, Madison Campbell and Leda Health have been involved in lawsuits and faced accusations of deceptive practices.

In June 2024, the Pennsylvania Attorney General's Office sued Leda Health and its CEO, Madison Campbell, alleging false claims in the marketing of their at-home rape kits. The lawsuit claimed the company misrepresented the value of their kits as substitutes for hospital-based evidence collection and their utility in criminal prosecutions. Leda Health subsequently filed a federal lawsuit against the Attorney General's office, alleging coercion and retaliation.

Additionally, in October 2022, the Attorney General's office in Washington state issued a cease-and-desist letter, stating that Leda Health's practices were "unfair and deceptive." In the past, when operating under the name "MeToo Kits Company," Leda Health also faced similar legal concerns from attorneys general in Illinois, Michigan, and New York.

Madison Campbell is mentioned as a co-founder of Leda Health alongside Liesel Vaidya in a Kyiv Post interview from December 2022. However, the search results do not indicate that Liesel Vaidya herself was directly targeted in any lawsuits, scandals, or controversies.

name: Bella Thorne
title: Actor
fraud:
Bella Thorne, who was named to Forbes' 2022 30 Under 30 list in Hollywood & Entertainment, has been involved in several controversies.

In 2020, Thorne joined OnlyFans and generated significant controversy. She claimed she was using the platform for research for a film role, but then offered pay-per-view photos she advertised as nude, which turned out to be lingerie pictures. This led to many users requesting refunds, which in turn allegedly prompted OnlyFans to implement new site-wide restrictions on content pricing and payment schedules. Sex workers criticized Thorne, blaming her for changes that negatively impacted their income.

Thorne has also accused actor Mickey Rourke of abusive and disturbing behavior on the set of their 2020 film "Girl." She alleged that Rourke repeatedly struck her pelvic area with a metal grinder during a scene, causing injury and distress. Rourke's representatives denied any intentional misconduct.

Additionally, in 2019, Thorne preemptively leaked nude photos of herself that hackers had threatened to release. While many supported her decision to reclaim her power, some, like Whoopi Goldberg, criticized her for taking such photos in the first place. There have also been accusations of Thorne using racial slurs in the past, though she has reportedly not addressed these claims. Thorne was also accused of copying a black-owned beauty brand's eyeshadow palette in 2018.

name: Jojo Siwa
title: Actor
fraud: In February 2024, Jojo Siwa and her mother, Jessalyn Siwa, were accused of creating a hostile work environment for members of their pop group, XOMG POP!. These accusations, detailed in a Rolling Stone article, include allegations of unpaid work, missed school, verbal abuse, and endangering the physical health of the young performers. Some reports claim that members were pressured to perform despite injuries and were not adequately compensated for their contributions.

name: Miranda Cosgrove
title: Actor
fraud:
Miranda Cosgrove has been involved in a few legal and controversial situations. In 2014, she was granted a restraining order against a stalker who had allegedly followed her, sent her gifts, and threatened suicide. The man was later arrested for violating the order. In 2016, a different man shot at a woman near Cosgrove's home before setting himself on fire and shooting himself in her yard.

Additionally, Cosgrove and her mother filed lawsuits claiming they were injured and disfigured after a tour bus crash in 2012. This accident led to the cancellation of her "Dancing Crazy" tour and resulted in significant financial losses, including lost income from canceled tour dates, and canceled endorsement deals with Neutrogena and Sony Music.

There are also allegations and discussions surrounding a "controversy" related to Dan Schneider, a producer with whom Cosgrove worked on Nickelodeon shows. Some sources suggest that Cosgrove, like other young actors, may have been subjected to uncomfortable situations or inappropriate content under his direction.

name: Laurel Schwartz
title: Brand Director
fraud: Laurel Schwartz, a Forbes 30 Under 30 honoree associated with Crisis Text Line, was not directly named in any lawsuits, scandals, or controversies found in the search results. However, Crisis Text Line itself faced scrutiny regarding its data-sharing practices with a for-profit spinoff company, Loris.ai. Privacy experts raised concerns that users might not have been fully aware of their anonymized data being shared, and questioned the ethics of potentially commercializing data from individuals in vulnerable situations. Crisis Text Line stated that personally identifiable information was not shared with Loris.ai and that their relationship with the company was public. The organization later ended its data-sharing relationship with Loris.ai due to community concerns.

name: Amanda Gorman
title: Poet
fraud: Amanda Gorman has been involved in a controversy regarding a book ban in a Florida school. A parent filed a complaint about Gorman's poem "The Hill We Climb," leading to the book being moved to a section of the school library for older students. Social media posts inaccurately claimed the poem was banned from all elementary schools in the county. Gorman expressed that she was "gutted" by the decision, and her publisher, along with other organizations like PEN America, has joined a lawsuit against another Florida school district that has banned books. Additionally, there was a controversy in the Netherlands where the initially chosen translator for Gorman's poetry withdrew after criticism that the translator was not Black.

name: Fletcher
title: Musician - Pop
fraud:
The musician Fletcher has faced accusations of sexual assault and knowingly infecting partners with STDs. She denies the assault charges but admits to having unprotected sex without disclosing her STD status. Fletcher has also sued one of her accusers for harassment. In a separate case, former San Diego County Supervisor Nathan Fletcher was dismissed from a lawsuit by a former employee who accused him of sexual assault and having her fired after their affair. The accuser claimed Fletcher engaged in discovery abuse, including altering and deleting evidence. Additionally, there have been controversies surrounding the release of Fletcher's song "Boy," with accusations of queerbaiting, particularly due to its release during Pride Month and messaging that some fans perceived as a betrayal of the LGBTQ+ community.

Several individuals featured on Forbes' "30 Under 30" list have faced legal issues. Charlie Javice, founder of the financial aid startup Frank, was convicted of defrauding JPMorgan Chase for inflating her company's customer numbers. She faces up to 30 years in prison and a separate civil trial from JPMorgan. Gökçe Güven, founder of the fintech startup Kalder, is charged with fraud for allegedly defrauding investors. Sam Bankman-Fried, founder of FTX, was arrested and charged with defrauding investors, leading to his company's bankruptcy, and was sentenced to prison. Joanna Smith-Griffin, founder of an education-technology startup, was charged with fraud for allegedly lying to investors.

name: Giveon
title: Musician - R&B
fraud: Giveon, who was featured on the Forbes 30 Under 30 list, has faced a public controversy regarding his past relationship with Justine Skye. In December 2021, Skye revealed on Instagram Live that she caught Giveon cheating by accessing his phone. She stated that she confronted him with screenshots, but he allegedly deflected and ended the relationship instead of apologizing.

name: Jack Harlow
title: Musician—Hip-hop
fraud: Lawsuit: Named in lawsuit related to fatal 2021 Derby Eve shooting where his DJ (Two Shell) killed bartender Kasmira Nash. Harlow dismissed from lawsuit (Apr 2025). Controversial 'Gang Gang Gang' song lyrics about friends accused of rape/pedophilia.

name: Klaudia Zadlo
title: Director
fraud: Charlie Javice, a Forbes 30 Under 30 honoree, has been involved in a significant lawsuit and controversy. She was accused of defrauding JPMorgan Chase by inflating her startup Frank's customer numbers to secure a $175 million acquisition deal. Prosecutors alleged that she claimed Frank had 4.25 million users when it actually had fewer than 300,000. This led to JPMorgan suing her for fraud after discovering the alleged deception. Javice, in turn, sued JPMorgan for legal costs and a retention bonus. She was found guilty of defrauding JPMorgan in March 2025. This case has drawn comparisons to the Theranos scandal and has been linked to a phenomenon some call the "Forbes 30 Under 30 curse," where individuals on the list have faced legal troubles.

name: Lil Durk
title: Musician - Hip-hop
fraud:
Lil Durk, who was featured on Forbes' 30 Under 30 list for 2022, has faced a significant lawsuit and allegations of ordering hits. In December 2023, a fintech startup named Exceed Talent Capital filed a $12 million lawsuit against Lil Durk, alleging "manifest fraud" in a deal to sell the rights to his song "Bedtime." The startup claimed that Lil Durk had already assigned these rights to a third party and that he had an exclusive contract with Alamo Records, which led to the legal action.

Furthermore, in October 2024, federal prosecutors accused Lil Durk of orchestrating a murder-for-hire plot in 2022. These accusations stem from an alleged plot to target rapper Quando Rondo as retaliation for the 2020 killing of Lil Durk's friend, King Von. Although Quando Rondo was not killed, his cousin, Savvia Robinson, was. Lil Durk is accused of ordering, funding, and directing the hit, leading to federal charges including conspiracy, firearm offenses, and murder for hire. It has also been reported that supporters of Lil Durk allegedly threatened the judge and prosecutors, and he was reportedly caught trying to destroy an Apple Watch while in jail.

name: Olivia Rodrigo
title: Musician—Pop
fraud:
Olivia Rodrigo has faced accusations of plagiarism, leading to retroactive songwriting credits for several of her songs. These claims primarily concern her debut album, "Sour." Specifically, songwriting credits were added for Taylor Swift and Jack Antonoff on "1 Step Forward, 3 Steps Back" (inspired by Swift's "New Year's Day") and "Deja Vu" (inspired by Swift's "Cruel Summer"). Additionally, Paramore's Hayley Williams and Josh Farro received credits on Rodrigo's hit "Good 4 U" due to similarities with Paramore's "Misery Business."

While these situations sparked significant online discussion and controversy, no lawsuits were officially filed against Rodrigo. Instead, agreements were reached regarding songwriting credits and monetization. Rodrigo herself has addressed the controversy, stating that "nothing in music is ever new" and that all music is inspired by each other. Her producer, Dan Nigro, also commented that "people get funny about things when songs become really popular," referencing the precedent set by previous music copyright disputes.

name: Issam Freiha and Vinay Menda
title: Cofounders
fraud: Blank Street Coffee, co-founded by Issam Freiha and Vinay Menda, is facing a trademark dispute with a London-based independent café also named Blank Coffee. The owners of Blank Coffee claim that Blank Street's branding is too similar, causing customer confusion and potential damage to their reputation. This legal challenge arose as Blank Street began expanding its operations into London. Blank Coffee is resisting Blank Street's attempt to register its trademark in the UK, asserting prior rights to the name.

name: Josh Deemer and Josh Pierce
title: Cofounders
fraud: A lawsuit was filed on February 17, 2025, by Alin Pop, on behalf of himself and others similarly situated, against JAXXON, LLC.. The class action lawsuit alleges that JAXXON engaged in deceptive, unfair, and misleading promotion of its products on social media platforms like Instagram. Specifically, the suit claims that influencers misrepresented their connection with JAXXON by endorsing products without disclosing that they were paid to do so, a practice the lawsuit describes as unfair and deceptive.. The lawsuit also suggests that this scheme was designed to artificially inflate product prices.. While Josh Deemer and Josh Pierce are founders of JAXXON, the lawsuit filing does not specifically name them as defendants, nor does it mention them by name in relation to the allegations.
